      Synthesis, crystal structure, Hirshfeld surface analysis, spectroscopic characterizations and electrical properties of the new complex of cobalt (III) and the Schiff-base of dihydroxycoumarin
      Ketata, Imen; Bejaoui, Linda; Brahmia, Ameni; Ben Hassen, Rached
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1246 (), 131161CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A new cobalt(III) complex, the [3,3'-{ethane-1,2-diylbis[(azanylylidene)eth-1-yl-1-ylidene]}bis [4-(hydroxy)-2H-1-benzopyran-2-onato]]-[bis(pyridine)]-cobalt chloradioxirane-1,1-dione hydrate, promising for its fluorescent and elec. properties was synthesized by the reaction of the Schiff-base '4-hydroxy-3-((E)-1-(2-((E)-1-(4-hydroxy-2-oxo-2H-chromen-3-yl)ethylideneamino)ethylimino)ethyl)-2H-chromene-2-one' and cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate under an oxygen-rich atm. The structure was detd. by single crystal x-ray diffraction and confirmed by FTIR and UV-visible spectroscopies. Hirshfeld's surface anal. indicates that the most important inter-mol. hydrogen bond within crystal packing is O-H···O interaction and the presence of a π-π stack was evident by the shape index and the curvature. It was also characterized for its high green emission in polar aprotic solvents using spectrofluorometry. Dielec. const. (ε'), dielec. loss (tan δ) and cond. (σ) were studied as a function of temp. and frequency. The results could be very significant in electronic and optoelectronic device applications.

      29b
      Green synthesis, SC-XRD, non-covalent interactive potential and electronic communication via DFT exploration of pyridine-based hydrazone
      Ali, Akbar; Khalid, Muhammad; Abid, Saba; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Iqbal, Javed; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Kanwal, Fariha; Lu, Changrui; ur Rehman, Muhammad Fayyaz
      Crystals (2020), 10 (9), 778CODEN: CRYSBC; ISSN:2073-4352. (MDPI AG)
      This study presents the sonochem. fabrication and characterization of a pyridine-based halogenated hydrazone, (E)-2-((6-chloropyridin-2-yl)oxy)-N'-(2-hydroxybenzylidene)acetohydrazide (HBPAH). The NMR spectroscopic technique was used to det. the structure, while SC-XRD confirmed its cryst. nature. Structural studies revealed that strong, inter-mol. attractive forces stabilize this cryst. org. compd. Moreover, the compd. was optimized at the B3LYP/6-311G(d,p) level using the Crystallog. Information File (CIF). Natural bonding orbital (NBO) and natural population anal. (NPA) were performed at the same level using optimized geometry. Time-dependent d. functional theory (DFT) was performed at the B3LYP/6-311G (d,p) method to calc. the frontier MOs (FMOs) and mol. electrostatic potential (MEP). The global reactivity descriptors were detd. using HOMO and LUMO energy gaps. Theor. calcns. based on the Quantum Theory of Atoms in Mols. (QT-AIM) and Hirshfeld analyses identified the non-covalent and covalent interactions of the HBPAH compd. Consequently, QT-AIM and Hirshfeld analyses agree with exptl. results.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhvValurbO&md5=191bb615583fba7f55c89fe54cad01ed
      open URL

      (c) Khalid, M.; Ali, A.; Haq, S.; Tahir, M. N.; Iqbal, J.; Braga, A. A. C.; Ashfaq, M.; Akhtar, S. U. H. Struct. 2021, 1224, 129308,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2020.129308
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29c
      O-4-Acetylamino-benzenesulfonylated pyrimidine derivatives: synthesis, SC-XRD, DFT analysis and electronic behaviour investigation
      Khalid, Muhammad; Ali, Akbar; Haq, Sadia; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Iqbal, Javed; Braga, Ataualpa A. C.; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Akhtar, Samee Ul Hassan
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1224 (), 129308CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Beginning with 2-amino-6-methyl-pyrimidin-4-ol and 2,6-diamino-pyrimidin-4-ol, 2-amino-6-methylpyrimidin-4-yl 4-acetamidobenzenesulfonate (APABS) and 2,6-diaminopyrimidin-4-yl 4-acetamidobenzenesulfonate (DPACS) were synthesized resp. through O-4-acetylamino-benzenesulfonylation reaction. The structures of the (APABS) and (DPACS) were verified unambiguously by the single crystal X-ray diffraction technique. The X-ray diffraction inspection inferred that these chem. architectures are stabilized by intermol. attractive forces. The quantum chem. examn. of optimized geometry, vibrational anal. and natural bond orbitals (NBOs) properties for APABS and DPACS were attained by adopting B3LYP/6-311G(d,p) level. Moreover, the frontier MOs (FMOs) anal. was detd. by TD-DFT/B3LYP/ 6-311G(d,p) level. The simulated structural parameters and XRD results of APABS and DPACS were found in close agreement to that of concerned exptl. findings. The mol. stability owing to strongest hyperconjugative interactions in APABS and DPACS was evaluated through NBO investigation. The transfer of charge phenomenon in the entitled compds. was evaluated by FMOs. The increasing order of energy gap for compds. is APABS<DPACS. Frontier MO energies of entitled compds. are also used to calc. the global reactivity indexes. The engagement of various sites in terms of chem. reactivities was detd. by mol. electrosatic potential anal. Moreover, Hirshfeld surfaces were studied which supported the X-ray diffraction investigation in terms of intermol. attractive forces.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      29d
      Single crystal investigation, Hirshfeld surface analysis and DFT exploration of the pyrimethamine-based novel organic salt: 2,4-diamino-5-(4-chlorophenyl)-6-ethylpyrimidin-1-ium 3-carboxybenzoate hydrate (1:1:1)
      Ashfaq, Muhammad; Bogdanov, Georgii; Glebov, Viktor; Ali, Akbar; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Abdullah, Safia
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1224 (), 129309CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      In current research work, synthesis of pyrimethamine-based novel org. salt: 2,4-diamino-5-(4-chlorophenyl)-6-ethylpyrimidin-1-ium 3-carboxybenzoate hydrate (1:1:1) (DECH) was reported. The org. salt was synthesized from acid base reaction of pyrimethamine and isophthalic acid. The structure of accomplished DECH was verified unambiguously by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD) anal. The SC-XRD investigation showed that anion and cation counterparts of org. salt form infinite 2D network due to N-H···O, C-H···O and O-H···O bonding. The weak interaction of type C-O···π was also assisting strengthening of crystal lattice of DECH. The mol. geometry of compd. in ground state was calcd. by using d. functional theory (DFT) method with 6-311++G(d,p) basis set and were compared with exptl. data. Addnl., HOMO-LUMO energy gap and mol. electrostatic potential (MEP) properties of compd. were performed at B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) level. Hirshfeld surface anal. of investigated DECH was used to confirm existence, strength and order of intermol. interactions in compd. The title org. salt appeared to be stable high reactive nucleophile.

      Intermolecular interactions in crystalline 1-(adamantane-1-carbonyl)-3-substituted thioureas with Hirshfeld surface analysis
      Saeed, Aamer; Bolte, Michael; Erben, Mauricio F.; Perez, Hiram
      CrystEngComm (2015), 17 (39), 7551-7563CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The conformationally congested species 1-(adamantane-1-carbonyl)-3-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)thiourea has been prepd. and fully characterized by elemental analyses, FTIR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and mass spectrometry. Its crystal structure was detd. by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The dihedral angle between the plane of the 2,4,6-trimethylphenyl group and the plane of the thiourea fragment was optimized by theor. calcns. applying the B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) level for the purpose of investigating the conformational effects on the stabilization of the crystal packing. A detailed anal. of the intermol. interactions in a series of six closely related phenylthiourea species bearing the 1-(adamantane-1-carbonyl) group has been performed based on the Hirshfeld surfaces and their assocd. two-dimensional fingerprint plots. The relative contributions of the main intermol. contacts as well as the enrichment ratios derived from the Hirshfeld surface anal. establish the 1-acyl thiourea synthon to be a widespread contributor.

      Structural Characterization, DFT, Hirshfeld Surface Analysis and Antibacterial Activity of a Schiff Base Derived from Cyclohexanediamine
      Nasaruddin, Nur Husnina; Ahmad, Shahrul Nizam; Sirat, Siti Syaida; Wai, Tan Kong; Zakaria, Nurul Aili; Bahron, Hadariah
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1232 (), 130066CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A new Schiff base derived from cyclohexanediamine and 3-methylsalicylaldehyde was obtained. The Schiff base, 6,6'-((1E,1'E)-(cyclohexane-1,2-diylbis(azanylylidene))bis(methanylylidene))bis(2-methylphenol), (AD2Me) was characterized through elemental anal., IR, UV-Vis, 1H and 13C NMR (NMR) spectroscopy. The structure of the grown crystal was elucidated by using single crystal X-ray diffraction technique. The compd. crystd. in the triclinic system, P-1 space group. The cell length and vol. for AD2Me are a = 10.4582(11) Å, b =10.8141(9) Å, c =18.7472(14) Å, α = 90.629(7)°, β = 92.444(7)°, γ = 109.561(9)° and V =1995.3(3) Å3, resp. The crystal structure is stabilized by intramol. hydrogen bond OH•••N and intermol. hydrogen bonds CH•••O, CH•••π and π•••π. The B3LYP method was used to calc. the optimized structure of the mol. through d. functional theory (DFT) using the 6-311G++(d, p) basis set and the results of the conformation anal. was in good agreement with the crystal structure detd. by x-ray single crystal diffraction. Addnl., the mol. electrostatic potential, frontier MOs and chem. reactivity descriptors of AD2Me were further investigated using DFT, revealing the electronic properties of the compd. A Hirshfeld surface anal. was performed to analyze intermol. interactions in the crystal structure. The compd. showed no significant activity against Staphylococcus aureus subsp. aureus Rosenbach (ATCC 6538) and Streptococcus mutans Clarke (ATCC 700610).

      32
      Intermolecular interactions in antipyrine-like derivatives 2-halo-N-(1,5-dimethyl-3-oxo-2-phenyl-2,3-dihydro-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzamides: X-ray structure, Hirshfeld surface analysis and DFT calculations
      Saeed, Aamer; Khurshid, Asma; Florke, Ulrich; Echeverria, Gustavo A.; Piro, Oscar E.; Gil, Diego M.; Rocha, Mariana; Frontera, Antonio; El-Seedi, Hesham R.; Mumtaz, Amara; Erben, Mauricio F.
      New Journal of Chemistry (2020), 44 (45), 19541-19554CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The synthesis, X-ray structure characterization, Hirshfeld surface anal. and DFT calcns. of two new antipyrine derivs. are reported herein. Particularly, 2-bromo-N-(2,3-dihydro-1,5-dimethyl-3-oxo-2-phenyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzamide (1) and 2-chloro-N-(2,3-dihydro-1,5-dimethyl-3-oxo-2-phenyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzamide (2) are synthesized in good yields and characterized spectroscopically. Both compds. are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic P21/c space group. The crystal packing of both compds. is mainly stabilized by a combination of N-H···O and C-H···O hydrogen bonds. In addn., C-H···π and lone pair···π contacts were obsd. Their solid-state structures have been analyzed through Hirshfeld surface anal., including the evaluation of the different energy frameworks, indicating that the mol. sheets are primarily formed by hydrogen bonds and the stabilization is dominated via the electrostatic energy contribution. These studies are complemented with DFT calcns. (B3LYP-D3/def2-TZVP), and a combination of QTAIM/NCIplot analyses disclosing that the H-bonding interactions are energetically relevant (ranging from 0.9 to 6.1 kcal mol-1), however the total binding energies of the different assemblies are dominated by a combination of π-interactions (of the type C-H···π, π···π, and lone pair halogen···π) that are able to stabilize cooperatively the assemblies up to 12 kcal mol-1.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXitFGlsLzM&md5=023a902ef22391f55f69e4c9dbaced8c

      Jelsch, C.; Ejsmont, K.; Huder, L. The enrichment ratio of atomic contacts in crystals, an indicator derived from the Hirshfeld surface analysis. IUCrJ 2014, 1, 119– 128,  DOI: 10.1107/s2052252514003327
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      33
      The enrichment ratio of atomic contacts in crystals, an indicator derived from the Hirshfeld surface analysis
      Jelsch, Christian; Ejsmont, Krzysztof; Huder, Loic
      IUCrJ (2014), 1 (2), 119-128CODEN: IUCRAJ; ISSN:2052-2525. (International Union of Crystallography)
      The partitioning of space with Hirshfeld surfaces enables the anal. of fingerprint mol. interactions in cryst. environments. This study uses the decompn. of the crystal contact surface between pairs of interacting chem. species to derive an enrichment ratio. This quantity enables the anal. of the propensity of chem. species to form intermol. interactions with themselves and other species. The enrichment ratio is obtained by comparing the actual contacts in the crystal with those computed as if all types of contacts had the same probability to form. The enrichments and contact tendencies were analyzed in several families of compds., based on chem. compn. and arom. character. As expected, the polar contacts of the type H···N, H···O and H···S, which are generally hydrogen bonds, show enrichment values larger than unity. O···O and N···N contacts are impoverished while H···H interactions display enrichment ratios which are generally close to unity or slightly lower. In arom. compds., C···C contacts can display large enrichment ratios due to extensive π···π stacking in the crystal packings of heterocyclic compds. C···C contacts are, however, less enriched in pure (C,H) hydrocarbons as π···π stacking is not so favorable from the electrostatic point of view compared with heterocycles. C···H contacts are favored in (C,H) aroms., but these interactions occur less in compds. contg. O, N or S as some H atoms are then involved in hydrogen bonds. The study also highlights the fact that hydrogen is a prefered interaction partner for fluorine.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXns1WhsL4%253D&md5=c158e85c14d08fd8faea094094582bc9
      open URL

      (a) Ali, A.; Kuznetsov, A.; Khan, M. U.; Tahir, M. N.; Ashfaq, M.; Raza, A.       [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      34a
      2-Amino-6-methylpyridine based co-crystal salt formation using succinic acid: Single-crystal analysis and computational exploration
      Ali, Akbar; Kuznetsov, Aleksey; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Raza, Abdul Rauf; Muhammad, Shabbir
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1230 (), 129893CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The current work reports the formation methodol. of the co-crystal between 2-amino-6-methylpyridine and succinic acid, its single-crystal characterization, and the computational study. The single-crystal anal. showed that the co-crystal mols. are interlinked by N···H-O and O···H-O bonds to form R22(8) loop and D22(5) and D22(8) finite pattern along with the formation of infinite 2D network in the (101) plane having base vectors [101] and [010]. The weak interactions of the π-π stacking type and C-O-Cg interactions are found in the title compd. helping in further strengthening of the crystal structure. The Hirshfeld surface anal. confirmed that H···H interat. contacts are the largest contributor to entire interat. contacts with contribution of 45.8%. The computational studies supported the presence of significantly strong H bonds within the title complex. The MO anal. suggested that both HOMO/HOMO-1 and LUMO/LUMO+1 would be able to participate in oxidative-reductive processes of the complex. The HOMO has dominating contributions from 1 succinate unit along with minor contributions from the H-bonded NH2-group of the neighboring 2-amino-6-methylpyridin-1-ium moiety. The calcd. values of the global reactivity parameters suggest noticeable stability of the title complex. It possesses quite pronounced nonlinear optical properties.

Synthesis of Diaminopyrimidine Sulfonate Derivatives and Exploration of Their Structural and Quantum Chemical Insights via SC-XRD and the DFT Approach. ACS Omega 2021, 6, 7047– 7057,  DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.0c06323
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      34b
      Synthesis of Diaminopyrimidine Sulfonate Derivatives and Exploration of Their Structural and Quantum Chemical Insights via SC-XRD and the DFT Approach
      Ali, Akbar; Khalid, Muhammad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Imran, Muhammad; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Hussain, Riaz; Assiri, Mohammed A.; Khan, Imran
      ACS Omega (2021), 6 (10), 7047-7057CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
      Two heterocyclic compds. named 2,6-diaminopyrimidin-4-ylnaphthalene-2-sulfonate (A) and 2,6-diaminopyrimidin-4-yl4-methylbenzene sulfonate (B) were synthesized. The structures of heterocyclic mols. were established by the X-ray crystallog. technique, which showed several noncovalent interactions as N···H···N, N···H···O, and C-H···O bonding and parallel offset stacking interaction. Hydrogen-bonding interactions were further explored by the Hirshfeld surface (HS) anal. Nonlinear optical (NLO) and natural bond orbital (NBO) properties were calcd. utilizing the B3LYP/6-311G(d,p) level. Frontier MOs (FMOs) and mol. electrostatic potential (MEP) were calcd. utilizing the time-dependent d. functional theory (TD-DFT) at the same level. The NBO anal. showed that the mol. stabilities of compds. A and B were attributed to their large stabilization energy values. The second hyperpolarizability (γtot) values for A and B were obtained as 3.7 x 104 and 2.7 x 104 au, resp. The exptl. X-ray crystallog. and theor. structural parameters of A and B were found to be in close correspondence. Both the mols. reveal substantial NLO responses that can be significant for their utilization in advanced applications.

      (a) Turner, M. J.; McKinnon, J. J.; Jayatilaka, D.; Spackman, M. A. Visualisation and characterisation of voids in crystalline materials. CrystEngComm 2011, 13, 1804– 1813,  DOI: 10.1039/c0ce00683a
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      35a
      Visualisation and characterisation of voids in crystalline materials
      Turner, Michael J.; McKinnon, Joshua J.; Jayatilaka, Dylan; Spackman, Mark A.
      CrystEngComm (2011), 13 (6), 1804-1813CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A method of mapping void space by rolling a probe sphere of variable radius over a fused-sphere representation of a mol. crystal has been developed. Based on isosurfaces of the procrystal electron d., this approach can be used to locate and visualize the void space in cryst. materials, as well as compute surface areas and vols. of the voids. The method is capable of locating and characterizing all "empty" space, and not just the larger cavities and channels, in mol. crystals, org., metal-org. and inorg. polymers. Comparison is made with existing computational methods, as well as with the results from exptl. techniques that provide ests. of vols. and surface areas of void space and porosity.

      35b
      Single-Crystal Investigation, Hirshfeld Surface Analysis, and DFT Study of Third-Order NLO Properties of Unsymmetrical Acyl Thiourea Derivatives
      Ashfaq, Muhammad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Muhammad, Shabbir; Munawar, Khurram Shahzad; Ali, Akbar; Bogdanov, Georgii; Alarfaji, Saleh S.
      ACS Omega (2021), 6 (46), 31211-31225CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
      In the current research work, unsym. acyl thiourea derivs., 4-((3-benzoylthioureido)methyl)cyclohexane-1-carboxylic acid (BTCC) and Me 2-(3-benzoylthioureido)benzoate (MBTB), have been synthesized efficiently. The structures of these cryst. thioureas were unambiguously confirmed by single-crystal diffractional anal. The crystallog. investigation showed that the mol. configuration of both compds. is stabilized by intramol. N-H···O bonding. The crystal packing of BTCC is stabilized by strong N-H···O bonding and comparatively weak O-H···S, C-H···O, C-H···π, and C-O···π interactions, whereas strong N-H···O bonding and comparatively weak C-H···O, C-H···S, and C-H···π interactions are responsible for the crystal packing of MBTB. The noncovalent interactions that are responsible for the crystal packing are explored by the Hirshfeld surface anal. for both compds. The void anal. is performed to find the quant. strength of crystal packing in both compds. Addnl., state-of-the-art applied quantum chem. techniques are used to further explore the structure-property relationship in the above-entitled mols. The optimization of mol. geometries showed a reasonably good correlation with their resp. exptl. structures. Third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) polarizability calcns. were performed to see the advanced functional application of entitled compds. as efficient NLO materials. The av. static γ amplitudes are found to be 27.30 x 10-36 and 102.91 x 10-36 esu for the compds. BTCC and MBTB, resp. The γ amplitude of MBTB is calcd. to be 3.77 times larger, which is probably due to better charge-transfer characteristics in MBTB. The quantum chem. anal. in the form of 3-D plots was also performed for their frontier MOs and mol. electrostatic potentials for understanding charge-transfer characteristics. We believe that the current investigation will not only report the new BTCC and MBTB compds. but also evoke the interest of the materials science community in their potential use in NLO applications.

      Synthesis, Crystal Structure, Hirshfeld Surface Analysis, and Computational Study of a Novel Organic Salt Obtained from Benzylamine and an Acidic Component
      Ashfaq, Muhammad; Munawar, Khurram Shahzad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Dege, Necmi; Yaman, Mavise; Muhammad, Shabbir; Alarfaji, Saleh S.; Kargar, Hadi; Arshad, Muhammad Umar
      ACS Omega (2021), 6 (34), 22357-22366CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
      A novel Schiff base compd. named as phenylmethanaminium (E)-4-((benzylimino)methyl)benzoate C7H10N+.C15H12NO2- (A) is synthesized by the chem. reaction of benzylamine and 4-carboxybenzaldehyde in ethanol, and the structure of the titled compd. is verified using the single-crystal X-ray diffraction technique. Structural investigation inferred that the crystal packing is mainly stabilized by N-H···O and comparatively weak C-H···O bonding between the cation and anion and further stabilized by weak C-H···π and C-O···π interactions. Hirshfeld surface anal. is employed to explore the noncovalent interactions that are responsible for crystal packing quant. Furthermore, we have used state-of-the-art quantum chem. calcns. to get comprehensive insights into the structure-optoelectronic property relationship for the entitled compd. The mol. geometry of compd. A is optimized at the M06/6-311G* level of theory. The linear polarizability, third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) polarizability, total and partial d. of states, and UV-visible spectrum are calcd. through quantum chem. calcns. We believe that compd. A is not only a new addn. to crystallog. data but also possesses good optical and NLO properties for its potential use in lasers and frequency-converting applications.

      (a) Braga, A. A. C.; Ujaque, G.; Maseras, F. A DFT Study of the Full Catalytic Cycle of the Suzuki–Miyaura Cross-Coupling on a Model System. Organometallics 2006, 25, 3647– 3658,  DOI: 10.1021/om060380i
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      37a
      A DFT Study of the Full Catalytic Cycle of the Suzuki-Miyaura Cross-Coupling on a Model System
      Braga, Ataualpa A. C.; Ujaque, Gregori; Maseras, Feliu
      Organometallics (2006), 25 (15), 3647-3658CODEN: ORGND7; ISSN:0276-7333. (American Chemical Society)
      A computational study with the Becke3LYP DFT functional is carried out on the cross-coupling reaction of vinyl bromide, H2C:CHBr and vinylboronic acid, H2C:CHB(OH)2 catalyzed by Pd diphosphine [Pd(PH3)2] in the presence of an excess of OH- base. The full catalytic cycle is computed, starting from the sepd. reactants and the catalyst and finishing with the cross-coupled product and the regeneration of the catalyst. The different stages in the cycle (oxidative addn., isomerization, transmetalation, reductive elimination) were characterized through calcn. of the corresponding intermediates and transition states. Different alternative mechanisms are considered, depending on the no. of phosphine ligands at Pd, and on the cis or trans isomery around the metal center. The results indicate the existence of a no. of competitive pathways of reasonably low energy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      37b
      Computational characterization of the role of the base in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction
      Braga, Ataualpa A. C.; Morgon, Nelson H.; Ujaque, Gregori; Maseras, Feliu
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (25), 9298-9307CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The role of the base in the transmetalation step of the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction is analyzed computationally by means of DFT calcns. with the Becke3LYP functional. The model system studied consists of Pd(CH:CH2)(PH3)2Br as the starting catalyst complex, CH2:CHB(OH)2 as the organoboronic acid, and OH- as the base. The two main mechanistic proposals, consisting of the base attacking first either the palladium complex or the organoboronic acid, are evaluated through geometry optimization of the corresponding intermediates and transition states. Supplementary calcns. are carried out on the uncatalyzed reaction and on a process where the starting complex is Pd(CH:CH2)(PH3)2(OH). These calcns., considered together with available exptl. data, strongly suggest that the main mechanism of transmetalation in the catalytic cycle starts with the reaction of the base and the organoboronic acid.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXkslGjur0%253D&md5=8263e3b127dc2ea5e2012401304eabb5
      open URL
      .
      (c) Braga, A. A. C.; Morgon, N. H.; Ujaque, G.; Lledós, A.; Maseras, F. Computational study of the transmetalation process in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling of aryls. J. Organomet. Chem. 2006, 691, 4459– 4466,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jorganchem.2006.02.015
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      37c
      Computational study of the transmetalation process in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling of aryls
      Braga, Ataualpa A. C.; Morgon, Nelson H.; Ujaque, Gregori; Lledos, Agusti; Maseras, Feliu
      Journal of Organometallic Chemistry (2006), 691 (21), 4459-4466CODEN: JORCAI; ISSN:0022-328X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      The transmetalation step of the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling between aryl groups is analyzed by DFT calcns. with the Becke3LYP functional. The halide considered is PhBr, and the organoboronic acid is PhB(OH)2. The model catalyst is Pd(PH3)2, and the base, OH-. The transmetalation is considered to start from the Pd(Ph)(PH3)2Br complex, the product of the oxidative addn. The results are compared with those of a previous study on the analogous reaction with vinyl groups, and it is shown that the reaction mechanism is very similar.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtVSit7fF&md5=93d1a9bc7ef8ebdfc9a62245fd56ac7d
      open URL
    38. 38
      Huang, C.-C.; Huang, Y.-C.; Hsieh, W.-C.; Chen, Y.-J.; Jiang, S.-K.; Chen, B.-H.; Hsu, I.-J.; Lee, J.-J. The effects of molecular structure and functional group of a rodlike Schiff base mesogen on blue phase stabilization in a chiral system. New J. Chem. 2019, 43, 1743– 1756,  DOI: 10.1039/c8nj04493g
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      38
      The effects of molecular structure and functional group of a rodlike Schiff base mesogen on blue phase stabilization in a chiral system
      Huang, Chiung-Cheng; Huang, Yu-Chang; Hsieh, Wei-Cheng; Chen, Yen-Jung; Jiang, Shi-Kai; Chen, Bo-Hao; Hsu, I.-Jui; Lee, Jey-Jau
      New Journal of Chemistry (2019), 43 (4), 1743-1756CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Two types of racemic rodlike Schiff base mesogens with -C=N- (type I) and -N=C- (type III) linkages were prepd. These mesogens possessed either difluoro substitutions at the inner-core position of the Ph ring or hydroxy group to form intramol. hydrogen bonding with an ester or/and imine linkage. When the appropriate concn. of chiral additive is doped into them, the incorporation of two fluoro substituents is more useful for blue phase (BP) stabilization than that of a hydroxy group near the ester linkage in Schiff base mesogens. BPI and BPII can be identified by reflectance spectra and polarized optical microscope images. BPII emerges easily on cooling when the appropriate chiral dopant ISO(6OBA)2 or chiral dopant S811 is doped into the Schiff base mesogen having only a hydroxy group near the ester linkage. Interestingly, BPI can be obsd. when 10-15 wt% ISO(6OBA)2 was doped into the difluoro substituted Schiff base mesogen during a heating process. The exptl. and mol. modeling results indicate that most of the difluorinated Schiff base mesogens with larger dipole moments exhibit wider BP ranges than their corresponding non-fluorinated homologues under the same chirality condition. In addn., wide BPs can be induced for racemic rodlike Schiff base mesogens in the chiral system and this is easier than that for racemic rodlike Schiff base mesogens. In Schiff base mesogens, the dipole moment is dominant for BP stabilization. However, the fluorine substituent effect is the main factor in Schiff base mesogens.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFejsL%252FE&md5=d3e1816d6a71a306ceff8af62d60a6dd

      Hanwell, M. D.; Curtis, D. E.; Lonie, D. C.; Vandermeersch, T.; Zurek, E.; Hutchison, G. R. Avogadro: an advanced semantic chemical editor, visualization, and analysis platform. J. Cheminf. 2012, 4, 17,  DOI: 10.1186/1758-2946-4-17
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      41
      Avogadro: an advanced semantic chemical editor, visualization, and analysis platform
      Hanwell, Marcus D.; Curtis, Donald E.; Lonie, David C.; Vandermeersch, Tim; Zurek, Eva; Hutchison, Geoffrey R.
      Journal of Cheminformatics (2012), 4 (), 17CODEN: JCOHB3; ISSN:1758-2946. (Chemistry Central Ltd.)
      Background: The Avogadro project has developed an advanced mol. editor and visualizer designed for cross-platform use in computational chem., mol. modeling, bioinformatics, materials science, and related areas. It offers flexible, high quality rendering, and a powerful plugin architecture. Typical uses include building mol. structures, formatting input files, and analyzing output of a wide variety of computational chem. packages. By using the CML file format as its native document type, Avogadro seeks to enhance the semantic accessibility of chem. data types. Results: The work presented here details the Avogadro library, which is a framework providing a code library and application programming interface (API) with three-dimensional visualization capabilities; and has direct applications to research and education in the fields of chem., physics, materials science, and biol. The Avogadro application provides a rich graphical interface using dynamically loaded plugins through the library itself. The application and library can each be extended by implementing a plugin module in C++ or Python to explore different visualization techniques, build/manipulate mol. structures, and interact with other programs. We describe some example extensions, one which uses a genetic algorithm to find stable crystal structures, and one which interfaces with the PackMol program to create packed, solvated structures for mol. dynamics simulations. The 1.0 release series of Avogadro is the main focus of the results discussed here. Conclusions: Avogadro offers a semantic chem. builder and platform for visualization and anal. For users, it offers an easy-to-use builder, integrated support for downloading from common databases such as PubChem and the Protein Data Bank, extg. chem. data from a wide variety of formats, including computational chem. output, and native, semantic support for the CML file format. For developers, it can be easily extended via a powerful plugin mechanism to support new features in org. chem., inorg. complexes, drug design, materials, biomols., and simulations.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsVGksLg%253D&md5=f10400f51db314afa780e99403ca748a

      43a
      Structural conformation and vibrational spectroscopic studies of 2,6-bis(p-N,N-dimethylaminobenzylidene) cyclohexanone using density functional theory
      James, C.; Raj, A. Amal; Reghunathan, R.; Jayakumar, V. S.; Joe, I. Hubert
      Journal of Raman Spectroscopy (2006), 37 (12), 1381-1392CODEN: JRSPAF; ISSN:0377-0486. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
      NIR-FT Raman and FT-IR spectra of the crystd. 2,6-bis (p-N,N-dimethylaminobenzylidene)cyclohexanone (C24H28N2O) have been recorded in the region 3200-500 and 4000-400 cm-1, resp. The spectral interpretation has been done following full structure optimization and vibrational wavenumber calcns. based on the d. functional theory (DFT) using the std. B3LYP/6-31G* basis set. The predicted vibrational spectra are in excellent agreement with the expt., permitting an unambiguous assignment for the unusual downshifting of νC=O caused by expanded conjugation effects in the dienone system. The optimized geometry clearly demonstrates the 'half-chair' conformation of the central nonheterocyclic ring. The ring C-H stretching vibrational modes involving arom. hydrogen atoms participating in steric interaction have been obsd. with low intensities. There are valid structural and spectral bases for the enhancement of its bioactivity due to full charge transfer reaction by the substitution of the electron-donating 4-dimethylamino group into the aryl rings. The existence of intramol., C-H···O, improper, blue-shifted hydrogen bond was investigated by means of the natural bonding orbitals (NBO) anal. There are also slight dissimilarities in the bond lengths and endocyclic bond angles of both Ph rings due to the effect of the heavy substitution. The characteristic ring modes have also been assigned in detail.

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      43b
      Crystal and molecular structure of 4-carboxypiperidinium chloride (4-piperidinecarboxylic acid hydrochloride)
      Szafran, M.; Komasa, A.; Bartoszak-Adamska, E.
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2007), 827 (1-3), 101-107CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      4-Piperidinecarboxylic acid hydrochloride, 4PCAH·Cl, has been characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) calcns., and FTIR spectrum. The crystals of the title compd. at room temp. are orthorhombic, space group P212121, with a = 7.0504(4), b = 7.5070(5), c = 15.3110(9) Å, V = 810.37(9) Å3, and Z = 4. The piperidine ring is protonated and adopts a chair conformation with the COOH group in the equatorial position. In the crystal structure, the Cl- anion is connected with the carboxyl group via an O=C-O-H···Cl- hydrogen bond of 3.022(2) Å. The Cl- anion is addnl. engaged in two N(1)+ -H···Cl- hydrogen bonds (3.168(2) and 3.186(2) Å) and one relatively short N(1)+···Cl- electrostatic interaction (4.603(2) Å). Five conformers of the title compd. have been examd. by the B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) method. Powder FTIR spectra of the title compd. and its deuterated analog are consistent with the X-ray structure.

      Srnec, M.; Solomon, E. I. Frontier molecular orbital contributions to chlorination versus hydroxylation selectivity in the non-heme iron halogenase SyrB2. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2017, 139, 2396– 2407,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b11995
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      44
      Frontier Molecular Orbital Contributions to Chlorination versus Hydroxylation Selectivity in the Non-Heme Iron Halogenase SyrB2
      Srnec, Martin; Solomon, Edward I.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (6), 2396-2407CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The ability of an FeIV=O intermediate in SyrB2 to perform chlorination vs. hydroxylation was computationally evaluated for different substrates that had been studied exptl. The π-trajectory for H-atom abstraction (FeIV=O oriented perpendicular to the C-H bond of substrate) was found to lead to the S = 2 five-coordinate HO-FeIII-Cl complex with the C• of the substrate, π-oriented relative to both the Cl- and OH- ligands. From this ferric intermediate, hydroxylation is thermodynamically favored, but chlorination is intrinsically more reactive due to the energy splitting between two key redox-active dπ* frontier MOs (FMOs). The splitting is detd. by the differential ligand field effect of Cl- vs. OH- on the Fe center. This makes chlorination effectively competitive with hydroxylation. Chlorination vs. hydroxylation selectivity is then detd. by the orientation of the substrate with respect to the HO-Fe-Cl plane that controls either the Cl- or OH- to rebound depending on the relative π-overlap with the substrate C radical. The differential contribution of the two FMOs to chlorination vs. hydroxylation selectivity in SyrB2 is related to a reaction mechanism that involves two asynchronous transfers: electron transfer from the substrate radical to the iron center followed by late ligand (Cl- or OH-) transfer to the substrate.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXht1Witr8%253D&md5=70b7957c9efa59bd0233ada17f996e55
      open URL

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      44b
      Theoretical study of corrosion inhibition of amides and thiosemicarbazones
      Kandemirli, Fatma; Sagdinc, Seda
      Corrosion Science (2007), 49 (5), 2118-2130CODEN: CRRSAA; ISSN:0010-938X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      An examn. of quantum chem. and corrosion inhibition studies were carried out to investigate whether any clear links exist between the results of quantum chem. calcns. and the exptl. efficiencies of urea (U), thiourea (TU), acetamide (A), thioacetamide (TA), semicarbazide (SC), thiosemicarbazide (TSC), methoxybenzaldehydethiosemicarbazone (MBTSC), 2-acetylpyridine-(4-phenyl)thiosemicarbazone (2AP4PTSC), 2-acetylpyridine-(4-methyl)thiosemicarbazone (2AP4MTSC), benzoin thiosemicarbazone (BZOTSC) and benzil thiosemicarbazone (BZITSC) being corrosion inhibitors. The quantum chem. calcns. have been performed by using DFT, ab-initio MO and semi-empirical methods for some amides and thiosemicarbozone derivs. being corrosion inhibitors. The HOMO energy, LUMO energy, the HOMO-LUMO energy gap, dipole moments (μ), charges on the C, O, N, S atoms, the total energies of the mols. and the polarizabilities 〈α〉, the coeffs. of the development of the MO over the AO corresponding to atoms between which a new bond is established have been calcd. The results of quantum chem. calcns. and exptl. efficiencies of inhibitors were subjected to correlation anal. We have reached the conclusion that the synthesis of better corrosion inhibitors can be achieved by controlling all electronic properties and parameters of a selected group of mols.

      Synthesis, characterization, crystal structures, Hirshfeld surface analysis and DFT computational studies of new Schiff Bases derived from Phenylhydrazine
      Parvarinezhad, Sakineh; Salehi, Mehdi
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2020), 1222 (), 128780CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      In this research, four novel ligands I [R1 = H, NO2; R2 = 4-MeO, 5-Br, Ph] were synthesized from hydrazine derivs. The hydrazine compds. via reacting 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine with 2-hydroxy-4-methoxybenzaldehyde/2-hydroxy- 5-bromobenzaldehyde/2-hydroxy-naphtaldehyde and 4-nitrophenylhydrazine with 2-hydroxy-4-methoxybenzaldehyde were synthesized, characterized using FT-IR, Raman and UV-Vis spectrum and it structure were confirmed by X-ray diffraction studies. Novel compds. were recovered to crystallize systems in monoclinic, orthorhombic, triclinic and monoclinic, crystal structures with P21/n, Pbcn, P-1, and P21/c space groups in ligands. Afterwards, present study compared exptl. parameters in UV-Vis and FT-IR spectra with theor. values. The results showed that at B3LYP/6-311 + G (d, p) level, DFT was able to properly reproduce structure of title ligands. Moreover, Hirshfeld surface (HS) anal., particularly dnorm surface and FPs (fingerprint plots), were employed to decode intermol. interactions in crystal system and contribution of component units in construction of 3D architecture. These examns. presented general description of such inter-contact interactions by means of an attractive graphical approach by 3D Hirshfeld surfaces and 2D fingerprint plots derived from the surfaces. Hirshfeld surface anal. indicated dominant role of various hydrogen intermol. interactions such as H···H, C···H/H···C and O···H/H···O for all compds. and H···Br contacts for ligand I [R1 = NO2, R2 = 5-Br] (because of the) into crystal packing which were discussed.

      Theoretical studies and spectroscopic characterization of novel 4-methyl-5-((5-phenyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl)thio)benzene-1,2-diol
      Soleimani Amiri, Somayeh; Makarem, Somayeh; Ahmar, Hamid; Ashenagar, Samaneh

      The structural, electronic, and spectroscopic properties of 4-methyl-5-((5-phenyl-1,3,4 oxadiazol-2-yl)thio)benzene-1,2-diol (MPOTB) have been carried out at ab initio and DFT levels. The electronic properties, such as mol. electrostatic potential, NBO at. charges, HOMO and LUMO energies were performed at above levels. Rather high hardness of MPOTB introduces it as a stable mol. As a result, the calcd. findings were compared with the obsd. values and generally found to be in good agreement.

      47a
      Electrophilicity Index
      Parr, Robert G.; Szentpaly, Laszlo v.; Liu, Shubin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1999), 121 (9), 1922-1924CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Prompted by a recent paper by Maynard and co-workers (Maynard, A. T.; Huang, M.; Rice, W. G.; Covel, D. G.; Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1998, 95, 11578), we propose that a specific property of a chem. species, the square of its electronegativity divided by its chem. hardness, be taken as defining its electrophilicity index. We tabulate this quantity for a no. of at. and mol. species, for two different models of the energy-electron no. relationships, and we show that it measures the second-order energy change of an electrophile as it is satd. with electrons.

      Khan, M. U.; Khalid, M.; Ibrahim, M.; Braga, A. A. C.; Safdar, M.; Al-Saadi, A. A.; Janjua, M. R. S. A. First Theoretical Framework of Triphenylamine-Dicyanovinylene-Based Nonlinear Optical Dyes: Structural Modification of π-Linkers. J. Phys. Chem. C 2018, 122, 4009– 4018,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.7b12293
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      49
      First Theoretical Framework of Triphenylamine-Dicyanovinylene-Based Nonlinear Optical Dyes: Structural Modification of π-Linkers
      Khan, Muhammad Usman; Khalid, Muhammad; Ibrahim, Muhammad; Braga, Ataualpa Albert Carmo; Safdar, Muhammad; Al-Saadi, Abdulaziz A.; Janjua, Muhammad Ramzan Saeed Ashraf
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2018), 122 (7), 4009-4018CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      This work was inspired by a previous report [Janjua, M.R.S.A. Inorg. Chem. 2012, 51, 11306-11314] in which the nonlinear optical (NLO) response strikingly improved with double heteroarom. rings. Herein, series of triphenylamine-dicyanovinylene based donor-π-acceptor dyes had been designed by structural tailoring of π-conjugated linkers and theor. descriptions of their mol. NLO properties were reported. D. functional theory and time-dependent d. functional theory calcns. were performed on optimized geometries to elucidate the electronic structures, absorption spectra, and NLO properties and also to shed light on how structural modification influences the NLO properties. The simulated absorption spectra results indicate that all of the dyes showed the max. absorbance wavelength in the visible region. The LUMO-HOMO energy gaps of all of the dyes have been found smaller, which results in large NLO response. Calcn. of natural bond orbital anal. reveals that electrons successfully migrated from donor to acceptor via π-conjugated linkers and a charge sepn. state was formed. High NLO response revealed that this class of metal free org. dyes possess eye-catching and remarkably large first hyperpolarizability values, esp. D8 with highest 〈α〉 and βtot computed to be 771.80 and 139 075.05 au, resp. Our research presented a vital confirmation for controlling the kinds of π-conjugated linker that was a significant approach for the design of new appealing NLO compds. This theor. framework also highlighted the NLO properties of org. dyes that can be valuable for their uses in modern hi-tech applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Khalid, M.; Ali, M.; Aslam, M.; Sumrra, S. H.; Khan, M. U.; Raza, N.; Kumar, N.; Imran, M.       [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      50
      Frontier molecular, natural bond orbital, UV-vis spectral study, solvent influence on geometric parameters, vibrational frequencies and solvation energies of 8-hydroxyquinoline
      Khalid, Muhammad; Ali, Muhammad; Aslam, Muhammad; Sumrra, Sajjad Hussain; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Raza, Nadeem; Kumar, Naresh; Imran, Muhammad
      International Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research (2017), 8 (2), 457-469CODEN: IJPSTT; ISSN:0975-8232. (International Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research)
      N-heterocyclic compds. have extensive biol. and pharmaceutical applications. 8-Hydroxyquinoline (8-HQ) also plays a significant role in many fields of life. The excellent biol. significance of the 8-HQ prompted us to extend the DFT based studies. The frontier MOs (FMOs), UV-Vis and solvation model based studies remained unknown. Therefore, we intended to study the natural bond orbital, FMOs, UV-Vis, thermodn. properties and medium influence on solvation energies, dipole moment, FT-IR and FT-Raman using polarizable continuum model (PCM) and d.-based solvation model (SMD). The electronic properties of mol. were calcd. by M06-2X/6-31G (d,P) and B3LYP/6-31G (d,p) level of theories. The solvent influence on the geometric parameters, FT-IR and FT-Raman were studied by B3LYP /6-31G(d) method. A good correspondence is found between the optimized parameters and the reported X-ray data. Natural bond orbital reveals that the max. stabilization energy reached up to 39.64 kJ/mol which is responsible for extra stability of the mol. In solvated 8-HQ, a significant medium effects on FT-IR and FT-Raman intensities is obsd. The intensities enhanced from gas to solvent phase. The solvation free energies are found to be -28.710 and -39.456 kJ/mol in PCM and SMD models resp. FMOs suggested that this mol. contain less hardness and larger softness values. These findings reveal that the mol. might be bioactive.

      Ibrahim, M.; Abbad, M.; Khaild, M. Phytochemical, crystal structure, spectroscopic, DFT based non covalent interactions and non-linear optical studies of neurada procumbens. J. Chem. Soc. Pak. 2018, 40, 749– 760
      [CAS], Google Scholar
      51
      Phytochemical, crystal structure, spectroscopic, DFT based non covalent interactions and non-linear optical studies of Neurada procumbens
      Ibrahim, Muhammad; Abbas, Mazhar; Khalid, Muhammad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Hussain, Ajaz; Ullah, Asmat; Hussain, Amjad
      Journal of the Chemical Society of Pakistan (2018), 40 (4), 749-760CODEN: JCSPDF ISSN:. (Chemical Society of Pakistan)
      In this study, two compds.: 4-(3-bromopropoxy)-3-methoxy Ph methanol (1) and 4-(3-bromopropoxy)-3-methoxybenzaldehyde (2) have been isolated from Neurada procumbens for the first time. Their structures have been elucidated by EI-MS, HR-EI-MS, HR-FAB-MS, 1H and 13C-NMR and XRD crystallog. techniques. These compds. have been further investigated using d. functional theory (DFT) at M06-2X level of theory with 6-311+G(d,p) basis set combination to obtain optimized geometry. The optimized geometrical parameters were found in good agreement with the XRD results. Natural bond orbital (NBO) anal. have been executed using M06-2X/6-311+G(d, p) level of theory which predicted the hydrogen bonding and hyper- conjugative interaction of both crystals. Frontier MO (FMOs) anal. and mol. electrostatic potential (MEP) surface studies were carried out using B3LYP/6-311+G(d,p) level to calc. EHOMO-ELUMO gap, possible sites and relative reactivities towards nucleophilic and electrophilic attack. Finally, nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of the title mols. were computed with B3LYP/6-311+G (d,p) method which is found greater as compared to the ref. mol. (urea) demonstrating that the mols. might have convincingly good NLO properties.

    52. 52
      (a) Medishetty, R.; Zaręba, J. K.; Mayer, D.; Samoć, M.; Fischer, R. A. Nonlinear optical properties, upconversion and lasing in metal-organic frameworks. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2017, 46, 4976– 5004,  DOI: 10.1039/c7cs00162b
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      52a
      Nonlinear optical properties, upconversion and lasing in metal-organic frameworks
      Medishetty, Raghavender; Zareba, Jan K.; Mayer, David; Samoc, Marek; Fischer, Roland A.
      Chemical Society Reviews (2017), 46 (16), 4976-5004CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The building block modular approach that lies behind coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) results not only in a plethora of materials that can be obtained but also in a vast array of material properties that could be aimed at. Optical properties appear to be particularly predetd. by the character of individual structural units and by the intricate interplay between them. Indeed, the "design principles" shaping the optical properties of these materials seem to be well explored for luminescence and second-harmonic generation (SHG) phenomena; these have been covered in numerous previous reviews. Herein, we shine light on CPs and MOFs as optical media for state-of-the-art photonic phenomena such as multi-photon absorption, triplet-triplet annihilation (TTA) and stimulated emission. In the first part of this review we focus on the nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of CPs and MOFs, with a closer look at the two-photon absorption property. We discuss the scope of applicability of most commonly used measurement techniques (Z-scan and two-photon excited fluorescence (TPEF)) that can be applied for proper detn. of the NLO properties of these materials; in particular, we suggest recommendations for their use, along with a discussion of the best reporting practices of NLO parameters. We also outline design principles, employing both intramol. and intermol. strategies, that are necessary for maximizing the NLO response. A review of recent literature on two-, three- and multi-photon absorption in CPs and MOFs is further supplemented with application-oriented processes such as two-photon 3D patterning and data storage. Addnl., we provide an overview of the latest achievements in the field of frequency doubling (SHG) and tripling (third-harmonic generation, THG) in these materials. Apart from nonlinear processes, in the next sections we also target the photonic properties of MOFs that benefit from their porosity, and resulting from this their ability to serve as containers for optically-active mols. Thus, we survey dye@MOF composites as novel media in which efficient upconversion via triplet energy migration (TEM) occurs as well as materials for stimulated emission and multi-photon pumped lasing. Prospects for producing lasing as an intrinsic property of MOFs has also been discussed. Overall, further development of the optical processes highlighted herein should allow for realization of various photonic, data storage, biomedical and optoelectronic applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVSis7jN&md5=c2c3c2a793c85c2bc81fd4aec53c6a05
      open URL
      .

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      52b
      Optical nonlinearity, limiting and switching characteristics of novel ruthenium metal-organic complex
      Manjunatha, K. B.; Rajarao, Ravindra; Umesh, G.; Ramachandra Bhat, B.; Poornesh, P.
      Optical Materials (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2017), 72 (), 513-517CODEN: OMATET; ISSN:0925-3467. (Elsevier B.V.)
      We report the nonlinear optical properties of Ruthenium metal complex, a promising org. material for use in scientific and technol. applications. The thin films of newly synthesized ruthenium metal-org. complex were fabricated using spin coating technique. Z-scan and degenerate four wave mixing (DFWM) techniques used to ext. the third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) parameters. The data reveals the investigated material exhibited relatively large NLO properties. The pump-probe expts. shows that the switch-on and off times of the material were in the order of μs at different pump intensities and the energy dependent transmission studies reveal good limiting property of the material in nanosecond regime.

Palladium-catalyzed synthesis of 5-(arylated) pyrimidines, their characterization, electronic communication, and non-linear optical evaluations. J. Mol. Struct. 2021, 1237, 130408,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2021.130408

      52c
      Palladium-catalyzed synthesis of 5-(arylated) pyrimidines, their characterization, electronic communication, and non-linear optical evaluations
      Khan, Ilham; Khalid, Muhammad; Adeel, Muhammad; Niaz, Shah Irum; Shafiq, Iqra; Muhammad, Shabbir; Braga, Ataualpa Albert Carmo
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1237 (), 130408CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      In this study, new derivs. of pyrimidines I [R1 = 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-Ph, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] were synthesized through Suzuki-Miyaura coupling and assessed by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, FT-IR and UV/Visible anal. Furthermore, computational study such as spectroscopic, frontier MO (FMO), natural bond orbital (NBO) and the mol. electrostatic potential (MEP) was performed at M06/6-311G** to obtain comprehensive insights into electronic communications and the structural property relationship for synthesized compds. I. The max. exptl. absorption (λExp) for compds. I [R1 = 4-Ph, 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] was obtained at 260, 301, 248, and 233 nm, resp. in methanol, which displayed good agreement with theor. (λDFT) result 279, 298, 247, and 233 nm, resp. Moreover, different functional(s) such as HF, M06, M062X, CAM-B3LYP, and LC-BLYP with basis sets 6-311G** were utilized to compute the av. polarizability α, total dipole moment (μtot) and hyperpolarizability (βtot) values. Among the tested methods, highest μtot value (3.5465 D) was obsd. for compd.I [R1 = 2,3-dichloro] and the lowest value (0.2680 D) for compd. I [R1 = 4-trifluoromethoxy] through HF method. Consequently, the LC-BLYP method also showed the highest μtot value (3.4689 D) for compd. I [R1 = 2,3-dichloro] and the lowest value (0.3123 D) of compd. I [R1 = 4-trifluoromethoxy]. Moreover, other methods: CAM-B3LYP, M062X, and M06 showed almost similar values for all compds. I with similar trends. The M06 method showed the largest α values (190.779, 149.331, 130.430 and 138.964 a.u.) for compds. I [R1 = 4-Ph, 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] resp. In contrast, the HF method showed the least α values (178.166, 140.356, 121.848, and 128.994 a.u.) for compds. I [R1 = 4-Ph, 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] resp. The other methods (CAMB3LYP, M062X, and LC-BLYP) indicated nearly parallel (α) values. Moreover, the (βtot) values (604.898, 344.234, 41.628, and 299.958 a.u.) obtained with M06 method for compds. I [R1 = 4-Ph, 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] resp., were higher compared with urea (βtot = 69.399 a.u.).
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      An efficient synthesis, structural (SC-XRD) and spectroscopic (FTIR, 1HNMR, MS spectroscopic) characterization of novel benzofuran-based hydrazones: An experimental and theoretical studies
      Khalid, Muhammad; Arshad, Muhammad Nadeem; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Asiri, Abdullah M.; Naseer, Muhammad Moazzam; Ishaq, Muhammad; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Shafiq, Zahid
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2020), 1216 (), 128318CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Herein, the benzofuran-based hydrazones derivs. such as N'-(1-(benzofuran-2-yl)ethylidene)isonicotinohydrazide (BEINH), N'-(1-(benzofuran-2-yl)ethylidene)nicotine-hydrazide (BFENH) and N'-(1-(benzofuran-2-yl)ethylidene)-2-chlorobenzohydrazide (BECBH)were synthesized and characterized using FTIR, 1HNMR, MS spectroscopic and SC-XRD techniques. Furthermore, the structural geometrical parameters, vibrational bands, natural bond orbitals (NBOs), natural population anal. (NPA), mol. electrostatic potential (MEP), linear and nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of the BEINH, BFENH and BECBH were rationalized applying B3LYP level of d. functional theory (DFT) inclusive of 6-311+G(d,p) basis set. Consequently, an excellent complement between the exptl. data and the DFT based results was attained. The most dominant hyper conjugative interactions with assocd. stabilization energies of 67.52, 59.61 and 48.35 kcal/mol were found for BEINH, BFENH and BECBH resp. which may become the cause of their stability. The band gaps (Egap) of BEINH, BFENH and BECBH were rationalized to be 3.814, 3.903 and 3.727eV resp. which can be efficiently polarized the chem. structures. The descending order of av. linear polarizability for title compds. is as: BECBH > BEINH > BFENH. It was conferred that highest value of βtot was obtained for BEINH as 3591.872 (a.u) and the smallest value was obtained for BECBHi.e. 2242.707 (a.u) among title compds. The overall decreasing order of βtot was obsd. as: BEINH > BFENH > BECBH. Addnl., NLO properties of title compds. were found larger than ref. material.

      Hameed, Kehkashan; Gilani, Syeda Rubina; Raheel, Ahmad; Taj, Babar; Iftikhar, Syed Hussan; Imtiaz-ud-Din; Sadiqa, Ayesha; Aslam, Ambreen

      57
      Glycine-d-tartaric acid (1/1)
      Mohandas, T.; Inbaseelan, C. Ranjith Dev; Saravanan, S.; Sakthivel, P.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section E: Structure Reports Online (2013), 69 (2), o236CODEN: ACSEBH; ISSN:1600-5368. (International Union of Crystallography)
      In the title co-crystal, C2H5NO2·C4H6O6, the glycine mol. is present in the zwitterion form. In the tartaric acid mol. there is a short intramol. O-H···O contact. In the crystal, the tartaric acid mols. are linked via pairs of O-H···O H bonds, forming inversion dimers. These dimers are linked via a no. of O-H···O and N-H···O H bonds involving the two components, forming a three-dimensional network. Crystallog. data and at. coordinates are given.

      Synthesis of a honeycomb-like Cu-based metal-organic framework and its carbon dioxide adsorption behaviour
      Sanz, Raul; Martinez, Fernando; Orcajo, Gisela; Wojtas, Lukasz; Briones, David
      Dalton Transactions (2013), 42 (7), 2392-2398CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Herein, the authors report on a new Cu-based MOF material, Cu2(dhtp), structurally homologous to the honeycomb-like M2(dhtp) series. This has been crystd. under solvothermal conditions using copper nitrate and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid as an org. linker, being the nature of the co-solvent in the synthesis media an important variable over the final phys. properties of the material. The presence of isopropanol as a co-solvent gives a pure cryst. phase with textural properties comparable to M2(dhtp) homologs. The interesting results in CO2 adsorption properties of this new material, esp. its isosteric heat of adsorption, make it a suitable MOF to be further evaluated under real conditions of industrial CO2 capture.

      Sheldrick, G. M. A short history ofSHELX. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A: Cryst. Phys., Diffr., Theor. Gen. Crystallogr. 2008, 64, 112– 122,  DOI: 10.1107/s0108767307043930
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      59
      A short history of SHELX
      Sheldrick, George M.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
      An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e
      open URL

      Kratzert, D.; Holstein, J. J.; Krossing, I. DSR: enhanced modelling and refinement of disordered structures withSHELXL. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2015, 48, 933– 938,  DOI: 10.1107/s1600576715005580
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      60
      DSR: enhanced modelling and refinement of disordered structures with SHELXL
      Kratzert, Daniel; Holstein, Julian J.; Krossing, Ingo
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2015), 48 (3), 933-938CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:1600-5767. (International Union of Crystallography)
      One of the remaining challenges in single-crystal structure refinement is the proper description of disorder in crystal structures. This paper describes a computer program that performs semi-automatic modeling of disordered moieties in SHELXL [Sheldrick (2015). Acta Cryst. C71, 3-8.]. The new program contains a database that includes mol. fragments and their corresponding stereochem. restraints, and a placement procedure to place these fragments on the desired position in the unit cell. The program is also suitable for speeding up model building of well ordered crystal structures.

      Chuchuryukin, A. V.; Huang, R.; Lutz, M.; Chadwick, J. C.; Spek, A. L.; Van Koten, G. NCN-Pincer Metal Complexes (Ti, Cr, V, Zr, Hf, and Nb) of the Phebox Ligand (S,S)-2,6-Bis(4′-isopropyl-2′-oxazolinyl)phenyl. Organometallics 2011, 30, 2819– 2830,  DOI: 10.1021/om200170b
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      61
      NCN-Pincer metal complexes (Ti, Cr, V, Zr, Hf, and Nb) of the Phebox ligand (S,S)-2,6-bis(4'-isopropyl-2'-oxazolinyl)phenyl
      Chuchuryukin, Alexey V.; Huang, Rubin; Lutz, Martin; Chadwick, John C.; Spek, Anthony L.; van Koten, Gerard
      Organometallics (2011), 30 (10), 2819-2830CODEN: ORGND7; ISSN:0276-7333. (American Chemical Society)
      Group IVB and VB metal NCN-pincer complexes of chiral 2,6-bis(2-oxazolinyl)phenyl ligands were prepd. as efficient catalysts for coordination polymn. of ethylene. Reaction of (S,S)-2,6-bis(4'-isopropyl-2'-oxazolinyl)phenyllithium (iPr-Phebox-Li) (2a) with 4,4'-bis[P-(chlorogold(I))diphenylphosphino]biphenyl [(dppbp)(AuCl)2] (5) afforded the new, bimetallic gold complex 4,4'-bis[P-(η1-C-iPr-Phebox-gold)diphenylphosphino]biphenyl [(P-Au(η1-C-iPr-Phebox))2(dppbp)] (6). Transmetalation of 6 with 2 equiv of Cl3MX (MX = TiOiPr, VCl, CrPy, ZrCl, HfCl, NbO) afforded the corresponding bis-monopincer compds. [MCl2X(iPr-Phebox)] (7a-c, M = Ti, V, Cr) and [MCl2X(iPr-Phebox)]2 (7a-c, M = Zr, Hf, Nb) in high yields and the gold starting material 5, which could be quant. recovered and reused. The structures in the solid state of the digold compd. 6, the monopincer compds. [(R-Phebox)Au(PPh3)] (4a,b, R = iPr, tBu), and a no. of Phebox-ETM complexes (7a, 7b, 7c, 8a, 8b, and 8c) were obtained. In each of these structures the i-Pr-Phebox monoanion is mer-N,C,N-tridentate bonded. The monopincer Phebox-Zr and -Hf compds. are dimeric because of two bridging chlorides, while the corresponding Nb compd. has bridging oxygen atoms. Reaction of 6 with iron(III) chloride resulted in the formation of a N4(FeCl2)2 complex, characterized by x-ray crystal structure detn., comprising a bridging, tetradentate N4 ligand formed by C-C coupling of two Phebox anions to a 2,2',6,6'-tetrasubstituted 1,1'-biphenyl species. The new Phebox complexes 7 and 8 have been tested as olefin polymn. precatalysts. Rapid catalyst deactivation was obsd. in ethene polymn. under homogeneous conditions, whereas stable activity was obtained after immobilization on MgCl2-based supports. From preliminary investigations on the reaction of 8a with either methylmagnesium chloride or methyllithium we assume that the low reactivity in homogeneous polymn. is due to the alkylation of the Phebox ligand.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXkvVOqurk%253D&md5=60afdf1a6b6329ebf6ec51cdfbe9e7cc
      open URL
    62. 62
      Macrae, C. F.; Sovago, I.; Cottrell, S. J.; Galek, P. T. A.; McCabe, P.; Pidcock, E.; Platings, M.; Shields, G. P.; Stevens, J. S.; Towler, M.; Wood, P. A. Mercury 4.0: From visualization to analysis, design and prediction. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2020, 53, 226– 235,  DOI: 10.1107/s1600576719014092
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      62
      Mercury 4.0: from visualization to analysis, design and prediction
      Macrae, Clare F.; Sovago, Ioana; Cottrell, Simon J.; Galek, Peter T. A.; McCabe, Patrick; Pidcock, Elna; Platings, Michael; Shields, Greg P.; Stevens, Joanna S.; Towler, Matthew; Wood, Peter A.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2020), 53 (1), 226-235CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:1600-5767. (International Union of Crystallography)
      The program Mercury, developed at the Cambridge Crystallog. Data Center, was originally designed primarily as a crystal structure visualization tool. Over the years the fields and scientific communities of chem. crystallog. and crystal engineering have developed to require more advanced structural anal. software. Mercury has evolved alongside these scientific communities and is now a powerful anal., design and prediction platform which goes a lot further than simple structure visualization.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXitlKhu7k%253D&md5=c16558a671e926b2350758305109b34c
      open URL
    63. 63
      Farrugia, L. J. WinGXandORTEP for Windows: an update. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2012, 45, 849– 854,  DOI: 10.1107/s0021889812029111
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      63
      WinGX and ORTEP for Windows: an update
      Farrugia, Louis J.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2012), 45 (4), 849-854CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (International Union of Crystallography)
      The WinGX suite provides a complete set of programs for the treatment of small-mol. single-crystal diffraction data, from data redn. and processing, structure soln., model refinement and visualization, and metric anal. of mol. geometry and crystal packing, to final report prepn. in the form of a CIF. It includes several well known pieces of software and provides a repository for programs when the original authors no longer wish to, or are unable to, maintain them. It also provides menu items to execute external software, such as the SIR and SHELX suites of programs. The program ORTEP for Windows provides a graphical user interface (GUI) for the classic ORTEP program, which is the original software for the illustration of anisotropic displacement ellipsoids. The GUI code provides input capabilities for a wide variety of file formats, and extra functionality such as geometry calcns. and ray-traced outputs. The programs WinGX and ORTEP for Windows have been distributed over the internet for about 15 years, and this article describes some of the more modern features of the programs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtVKltbzK&md5=0b5b2b5facbaafdd6bbbb80e581bf3be
      open URL

      1. 1
        Cimerman, Z.; Miljanić, S.; Galić, N. Schiff bases derived from aminopyridines as spectrofluorimetric analytical reagents. Croat. Chem. Acta 2000, 73, 81– 95
        [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Schiff bases derived from aminopyridines as spectrofluorimetric analytical reagents
        Cimerman, Zujezdana; Miljanic, Snezana; Galic, Nives
        Croatica Chemica Acta (2000), 73 (1), 81-95CODEN: CCACAA; ISSN:0011-1643. (Croatian Chemical Society)
        Fluorescence characteristics of Schiff bases derived from aminopyridines and salicylaldehyde were studied and possibilities of their anal. application are discussed. These compds. can be used for spectrofluorometric monitoring of small pH changes as well as for sensitive metal ion detns. As an illustration of metal ion detn., a spectrofluorometric procedure for anal. of Cu2+ is presented. Detn. of Cu2+ was based on the quenching effect of Cu2+ on the fluorescence of N,N'-bis(salicylidene)-2,3-pyridinediamine in dioxan/H2O 1/1 (vol. fraction of dioxan, φ= 50%). Under optimal conditions (pH = 8.9, λex = 340 nm, λem = 385 nm, cligand = 1.0 × 10-5 M), the linearity range of the calibration curve was 30-350 μg L-1 Cu2+. The procedure is fast, simple and reproducible. It was characterized by high sensitivity and satisfactory selectivity. An addnl. advantage of Schiff bases derived from aminopyridines as anal. reagents lies in the simplicity of prepn. procedures, enabling improvement of the detn. methods not only by optimization of exptl. conditions, but also by designing suitable structural characteristics of the reagent.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXhvFSjsbg%253D&md5=9563b310f046370609f4917fcde78305
        open URL
      2. 2
        Abu-Dief, A. M.; Mohamed, I. M. A. A review on versatile applications of transition metal complexes incorporating Schiff bases. Beni-Seuf Univ. J. Appl. Sci. 2015, 4, 119– 133,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bjbas.2015.05.004
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        A review on versatile applications of transition metal complexes incorporating Schiff bases
        Abu-Dief Ahmed M; Mohamed Ibrahim M A; Abu-Dief Ahmed M
        Beni-Suef University journal of basic and applied sciences (2015), 4 (2), 119-133 ISSN:.
        Schiff bases and their complexes are versatile compounds synthesized from the condensation of an amino compound with carbonyl compounds and widely used for industrial purposes and also exhibit a broad range of biological activities including antifungal, antibacterial, antimalarial, antiproliferative, anti-inflammatory, antiviral, and antipyretic properties. Many Schiff base complexes show excellent catalytic activity in various reactions and in the presence of moisture. Over the past few years, there have been many reports on their applications in homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. The high thermal and moisture stabilities of many Schiff base complexes were useful attributes for their application as catalysts in reactions involving at high temperatures. The activity is usually increased by complexation therefore to understand the properties of both ligands and metal can lead to the synthesis of highly active compounds. The influence of certain metals on the biological activity of these compounds and their intrinsic chemical interest as multidentate ligands has prompted a considerable increase in the study of their coordination behaviour. Development of a new chemotherapeutic Schiff bases and their metal complexes is now attracting the attention of medicinal chemists. This review compiles examples of the most promising applied Schiff bases and their complexes in different areas.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB38zltV2ksw%253D%253D&md5=b562354ff14b934782ccd236cd6d2496
        open URL
      3. 3
        Ali, S. M. M.; Azad, M. A. K.; Jesmin, M.; Ahsan, S.; Rahman, M. M.; Khanam, J. A.; Islam, M. N.; Shahriar, S. M. S. In vivo anticancer activity of vanillin semicarbazone. Asian Pac. J. Trop. Biomed. 2012, 2, 438– 442,  DOI: 10.1016/s2221-1691(12)60072-0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        In vivo anticancer activity of vanillin semicarbazone
        Ali, Shaikh M. Mohsin; Azad, M. Abul Kalam; Jesmin, Mele; Ahsan, Shamim; Rahman, A. Mijanur; Khanam, Jahan Ara; Islam, M. Nazrul; Shahriar, Sha M. Shahan
        Asian Pacific Journal of Tropical Biomedicine (2012), 2 (6), 438-442CODEN: APJTC7; ISSN:2221-1691. (Asian Pacific Tropical Medicine Press)
        Objective: To evaluate the anticancer activity of vanillin semicarbazone (VSC) against Ehrlich ancites carcinoma (EAC) cells in Swiss albino mice. Methods: The compd. VSC at three doses (5, 7.5 and 10 mg/kg i.p.) was administered into the i.p. cavity of the EAC inoculated mice to observe its efficiency by studying the cell growth inhibition, redn. of tumor wt., enhancement of survival time as well as the changes in depleted hematol. parameters. All such parameters were also studied with a known std. drug bleomycin at the dose of 0.3 mg/kg (i.p.). Results: Among the doses studied, 10 mg/kg (i.p.) was found to be quite comparable in potency to that of bleomycin at the dose of 0.3 mg/kg (i.p.). The host toxic effects of VSC was found to be negligible. Conclusions: It can be concluded that VSC can therefore be considered as potent anticancer agent.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XotVOgsbY%253D&md5=0a42660bd5686d6d23ec90fbfc0e40fd

      4. 4
        Sondhi, S. M.; Singh, N.; Kumar, A.; Lozach, O.; Meijer, L. Synthesis, anti-inflammatory, analgesic and kinase (CDK-1, CDK-5 and GSK-3) inhibition activity evaluation of benzimidazole/benzoxazole derivatives and some Schiff’s bases. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2006, 14, 3758– 3765,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2006.01.054
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4
        Synthesis, anti-inflammatory, analgesic and kinase (CDK-1, CDK-5 and GSK-3) inhibition activity evaluation of benzimidazole/benzoxazole derivatives and some Schiff's bases
        Sondhi, Sham M.; Singh, Nirupma; Kumar, Ashok; Lozach, Olivier; Meijer, Laurent
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2006), 14 (11), 3758-3765CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A series of N-(acridin-9-yl)-4-(benzo[d]imidazol/oxazol-2-yl) benzamides has been synthesized by the condensation of 9-aminoacridine derivs. with benzimidazole or benzoxazole derivs. Condensation of 2-hydroxy naphthaldehyde with functionalized diamines leads to the formation of Schiff's bases and not imidazole derivs. All these compds. were characterized by correct FT-IR, 1H NMR, MS and elemental analyses. These compds. were screened for anti-inflammatory, analgesic and kinase (CDK-1, CDK-5 and GSK-3) inhibition activities. Compds. (I) and a mixt. (II, III) showed good anti-inflammatory (35.8% at 50 mg/kg po) activity and good analgesic activity (60% at 50 mg/kg po), resp. Compd. (IV) showed significant in vitro activity against CDK-5 (IC50 = 4.6 μM) and CDK-1(IC50 = 7.4 μM) and compd. (V) showed moderate CDK-5 inhibitory activity (IC50 = 7.5 μM). The other compds. showed moderate anti-inflammatory and analgesic activities.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XjvFWmsrY%253D&md5=926ba3d5f6608b998ae0043333ab76e7
