      5. 5
        Aboul-Fadl, T.; Mohammed, F. A.-H.; Hassan, E. A.-S. Synthesis, antitubercular activity and pharmacokinetic studies of some schiff bases derived from 1- alkylisatin and isonicotinic acid hydrazide (inh). Arch Pharm. Res. 2003, 26, 778– 784,  DOI: 10.1007/bf02980020
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Synthesis, antitubercular activity and pharmacokinetic studies of some Schiff bases derived from 1-alkylisatin and isonicotinic acid hydrazide (INH)
        Aboul-fadl, Tarek; Abdel-hamid. Mohammed, Faragany; Abdel-saboor Hassan, Ehsan
        Archives of Pharmacal Research (2003), 26 (10), 778-784CODEN: APHRDQ; ISSN:0253-6269. (Pharmaceutical Society of Korea)
        N-(1-alkyl-2,3-dihydro-2-oxo-1H-3-indolyliden)-4-pyridinecarboxylic acid hydrazide derivs., were synthesized in a trial to overcome the resistance developed with the therapeutic uses of isoniazid (INH). The lipophilicity of the synthesized derivs. supersedes that of the INH as expressed by Clog p values. The synthesized compds. and INH were tested against bovine, human sensitive and human resist strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Compds. with 1-unsubstituted, 1-Pr, 1-propynyl and 1-benzyl groups resp. exhibited equipotent growth inhibitory activity (MIC 10 μmol) against the tested strains as compared with INH however the later has no activity against human resist strain. Pharmacokinetic study revealed that the rate and extent of absorption of the tested derivs. was significantly higher than that of INH (p<0.05). The relative bioavailabilities (FR%) were 183.15 and 443.25 for derivs. as compared to INH. These results preliminary indicate the possible use of the prepd. derivs. for treatment of tuberculosis infections in order to overcome the resistance developed with INH.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXptVGiuro%253D&md5=8dcc0a8ce207853aed891a00e4eebe02

      6. 6
        Mounika, K.; Pragathi, A.; Gyanakumari, C. Synthesis, Characterization and Biological Activity of a Schiff Base Derived from 3-Ethoxy Salicylaldehyde and 2-Amino Benzoic acid and its Transition Metal Complexes. J. Sci. Res. 2010, 2, 513,  DOI: 10.3329/jsr.v2i3.4899
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6
        Synthesis, characterization and biological activity of a Schiff base derived from 3-ethoxy salicylaldehyde and 2-amino benzoic acid and its transition metal complexes
        Mounika, K.; Anupama, B.; Pragathi, J.; Gyanakumari, C.
        Journal of Scientific Research (Rajshahi, Bangladesh) (2010), 2 (3), 513-524CODEN: JSRRBO; ISSN:2070-0245. (Rajshahi University, Faculty of Sciences)
        A new Schiff base, (3-ethoxysalicylideneamino)benzoic acid (ETSAN), has been synthesized from 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde and 2-aminobenzoic acid. Metal complexes of the Schiff base were prepd. from nitrate/chloride salts of Ni(II), Co(II) Cu(II) and Zn(II) in an alc. medium. The complexes are non-electrolytes in DMSO solvent (DMSO). The chem. structures of the Schiff-base ligand and its metal complexes were confirmed by various spectroscopic studies like IR, UV-VIS, 1H NMR, 13C NMR, ESI-mass spectra, elemental anal., molar conductance, thermogravimetric studies and magnetic susceptibility measurements. On the basis of elemental and spectral studies, a six-coordinated geometry was assigned to these complexes. In the light of these results, it is suggested that this ligand acts as neutral and tridentate and coordinates to each metal atom by the azomethine nitrogen and oxygen atoms of the hydroxyl group of the 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde, in addn. to the carboxy group of 2-aminobenzoic acid. The mass spectral data confirms the monomeric structure of the metal complexes while the TGA studies confirm the presence of water mols. in the complex. The free Schiff base and its complexes have been tested for their antibacterial as well as antifungal activity by using disk diffusion method and the results discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsVWktrbK&md5=b4df3aecdbb7dbc4edf4148136c1d108

        Avaji, P. G.; Vinod Kumar, C. H.; Patil, S. A.; Shivananda, K. N.; Nagaraju, C. Synthesis, spectral characterization, in-vitro microbiological evaluation and cytotoxic activities of novel macrocyclic bis hydrazone. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2009, 44, 3552– 3559,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2009.03.032
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        Synthesis, spectral characterization, in-vitro microbiological evaluation and cytotoxic activities of novel macrocyclic bis hydrazone
        Avaji, Prakash Gouda; Vinod Kumar, C. H.; Patil, Sangamesh A.; Shivananda, K. N.; Nagaraju, C.
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2009), 44 (9), 3552-3559CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A macrocyclic hydrazone Schiff base was synthesized by reacting 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid dihydrazide with 2,6-diformyl-4-Me phenol and a series of metal complexes with this new Schiff base were synthesized by reaction with Co(II), Ni(II) and Cu(II) metal salts. The Schiff base and its complexes have been characterized by elemental analyses, IR, 1H NMR, UV-vis, FAB mass, ESR spectra, fluorescence, thermal, magnetic and molar conductance data. The anal. data reveal that the Co(II), Ni(II) and Cu(II) complexes possess 2:1 metal-ligand ratios. All the complexes are non-electrolytes in DMF and DMSO due to their low molar conductance values. IR spectral data suggest that the hydrazone Schiff base behaves as a hexadentate ligand with NON NON donor sequence towards the metal ions. The ESR spectral data shows that the metal-ligand bond has considerable covalent character. The electrochem. behavior of the copper(II) complex was investigated by cyclic voltammetry. The Schiff base and its complexes have also been screened for their antibacterial (Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, Shigella dysentery, Micrococcus, Bacillus subtilis, Bacillus cereus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) and antifungal activities (Aspergillus niger, Penicillium and Candida albicans) by MIC method. The brine shrimp bioassay was also carried out to study their in-vitro cytotoxic properties.

        Synthesis, catalytic and biological activity of novel dinuclear copper complex with Schiff base
        Wei, Danyi; Li, Ning; Lu, Gui; Yao, Kemin
        Science in China, Series B: Chemistry (2006), 49 (3), 225-229CODEN: SCBCFQ; ISSN:1006-9291. (Science in China Press)
        A novel dinuclear copper complex with tetraglycol aldehyde-phenylalanine Schiff base has been synthesized. It was characterized and formulated as [Cu2L(NO3)]NO3 by elemental anal., magnetic susceptibility, TG-DTA, IR, EPR, and 1H NMR spectra. The obtained complex can be used as a good catalyst for the polymn. of Me methacrylate (MMA). The optimum polymn. conditions are: MMA/catalyst = 500 (molar ratio); [catalyst] = 7.5 × 10-3 mol/L-1; dioxane as solvent; 80°, 6 h. Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) with 80% conversion, 7.2 × 105 viscosity-av. mol. wt. and 60.5% syndiotacticity was obtained. This complex has also been shown to play an important role in scavenging .

        (a) Martin, S. F. Recent applications of imines as key intermediates in the synthesis of alkaloids and novel nitrogen heterocycles. Pure Appl. Chem. 2009, 81, 195– 204,  DOI: 10.1351/pac-con-08-07-03
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11a
        Recent applications of imines as key intermediates in the synthesis of alkaloids and novel nitrogen heterocycles
        Martin, Stephen F.
        Pure and Applied Chemistry (2009), 81 (2), 195-204CODEN: PACHAS; ISSN:0033-4545. (International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry)
        A review. One of the major challenges in contemporary synthetic org. chem. is the design and development of new tactics and strategies and their application to concise and efficient syntheses of biol. active natural products. Strategies that utilize reactions that enable the rapid assembly of the skeletal framework of such targets are thus esp. attractive. In this context, novel applications of imine chem. in Mannich and related reactions, cascade processes, and multicomponent reactions (MCRs) have been developed to rapidly assemble structural subunits common to diverse families of alkaloids. The practical utility of these chemistries is evidenced by their use in the execution of facile total syntheses of (±)-epilupinine, (±)-tashiromine, (-)-epimyrtine, and (±)-roelactamine as well as other nitrogen heterocycles of potential biol. interest.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXisFGiu7g%253D&md5=8bd1c75b722175b22766575ccafbe8b1

        (c) de la Torre, A. F.; Ali, A.; Concepcion, O.; Montero-Alejo, A. L.; Muñiz, F. M.; Jiménez, C. A.; Belmar, J.; Velázquez-Libera, J. L.; Hernández-Rodríguez, E. W.; Caballero, J.         [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11c
        A study of the cis-trans isomerization preference of N-alkylated peptides containing phosphorus in the side chain and backbone
        de la Torre, Alexander F.; Ali, Akbar; Concepcion, Odette; Montero-Alejo, Ana L.; Muniz, Francisco M.; Jimenez, Claudio A.; Belmar, Julio; Velazquez-Libera, Jose Luis; Hernandez-Rodriguez, Erix W.; Caballero, Julio
        New Journal of Chemistry (2019), 43 (32), 12804-12813CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The current work provides a study on the cis-trans isomerization behavior of N-alkylated peptides decorated with phosphonate ester groups. A Ugi four-component reaction was chosen for the synthesis of N-alkylated peptides, where almost only the cis isomer was detected when the phosphonate ester group was incorporated as an amine component in the side chain. However, the phosphonate ester group inserted in the backbone, as an isocyanide component, leads preferably to the trans isomer of this kind of peptides. The diverse behavior of cis-trans isomerization has been explained via spectroscopic NMR anal. and computational calcns.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhsVWkurrI&md5=6751c61d77a84656769244739d637c33

        (a) Ali, A.; Khalid, M.; Rehman, M. F. U.; Haq, S.; Ali, A.; Tahir, M. N.; Ashfaq, M.; Rasool, F.; Braga, A. A. C. Efficient Synthesis, SC-XRD, and Theoretical Studies of O-Benzenesulfonylated Pyrimidines: Role of Noncovalent Interaction Influence in Their Supramolecular Network.         [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12a
        Efficient Synthesis, SC-XRD, and Theoretical Studies of O-Benzenesulfonylated Pyrimidines: Role of Noncovalent Interaction Influence in Their Supramolecular Network
        Ali, Akbar; Khalid, Muhammad; Rehman, Muhammad Fayyaz ur; Haq, Sadia; Ali, Arif; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Rasool, Faiz; Braga, Ataualpa Albert Carmo
        ACS Omega (2020), 5 (25), 15115-15128CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
        Pyrimidinyl benzenesulfonates I (R = Me, H2N) were prepd. from the corresponding pyrimidinols by sulfonylation with benzenesulfonyl chloride. The structures of I were detd. by X-ray crystallog.; detn. of Hirshfeld surfaces for I indicated that C-H···O, N-H···N, and C-H···C hydrogen bond interactions were the major contributors to intermol. stabilization in the crystal. The vibrational frequencies, FMO, electrostatic potential, ionization potential, electron affinity, polarizabilities, and hyperpolarizabilities of I were detd. computationally and were consistent with the properties obsd. in the crystal structures of I.

        12b
        Facile Ultrasound-Based Synthesis, SC-XRD, DFT Exploration of the Substituted Acyl-Hydrazones: An Experimental and Theoretical Slant towards Supramolecular Chemistry
        Khalid, Muhammad; Ali, Akbar; Abid, Saba; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Imran, Muhammad; Ahmad, Anees
        ChemistrySelect (2020), 5 (47), 14844-14856CODEN: CHEMUD; ISSN:2365-6549. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        An efficient ultrasound-based synthesis of substituted acyl-hydrazones I [R = 4-methylbenzylidene, 3-phenylprop-2-enylidene], single crystal anal. and DFT exploration was reported. The substituted acyl-hydrazones I synthesis was accomplished utilizing sono-chem. approach. The structures of these mols. I were characterized with NMR and SC-XRD anal. The exptl. and theor. anal. employed to det. non-covalent, hyper-conjugative interactions and favorable sites for reactivity. Time-dependent d. functional theory (TD-DFT) approach was utilized to acquire insights about FMO anal. The global reactivity parameters established with aid of HOMO and LUMO energies. QT-AIM and Hirshfeld analyses were computed to quantify non-covalent interactions for both crystals. Theor. obsd. structural chem. of both crystals led to a fabulous overall agreement with obtained SC-XRD patterns. The mol. stability and bond strengths of the aforesaid mols. were imparted owing to hyper-conjugative interactions as well as charge delocalization process. Moreover, NBO based findings were rationalized to Hirshfeld anal. and SC-XRD data.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXis1GntLjJ&md5=8e2ceb50f997b630fc29817b3c70cac2
        open URL
        .
        (c) Khalid, M.; Ali, A.; De la Torre, A. F.; Marrugo, K. P.; Concepcion, O.; Kamal, G. M.; Muhammad, S.; Al-Sehemi, A. G. Facile Synthesis, Spectral (IR, Mass, UV–Vis, NMR), Linear and Nonlinear Investigation of the Novel Phosphonate Compounds: A Combined Experimental and Simulation Study.         12c
        Facile Synthesis, Spectral (IR, Mass, UV-Vis, NMR), Linear and Nonlinear Investigation of the Novel Phosphonate Compounds: A Combined Experimental and Simulation Study
        Khalid, Muhammad; Ali, Akbar; De la Torre, Alexander F.; Marrugo, Kelly P.; Concepcion, Odette; Kamal, Ghulam Mustafa; Muhammad, Shabbir; Al-Sehemi, Abdullah G.
        ChemistrySelect (2020), 5 (10), 2994-3006CODEN: CHEMUD; ISSN:2365-6549. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Herein, authors reported the imino phosphonate compds.: (4-methoxy-benzylidene-amino-phenyl-methyl-phosphonic acid di-Et ester (MBPDE), 4-hydroxy-benzylidene-amino-phenyl-methyl-phosphonic acid di-Et ester (HBPDE) and 4-hydroxy-3-methoxy-benzylidene-amino-phenyl-methyl-phosphonic acid di-Et ester (HMBPD)) form the chem. reaction of di-Et (α-amino benzyl)phosphonate hydrochloride and substituted benzaldehyde. These compds. were characterized by various spectroscopic techniques: FT-IR, Mass, UV-VIS, 1H NMR and 13C NMR. Addnl., the optimized mol. structures, FT-IR, natural bond orbitals (NBOs), frontier MOs (FMOs), non-linear optical (NLO) properties were calcd. by the d. functional theory (DFT) using the B3LYP functional with the 6-311+G(d,p) basis set. Moreover, UV-Visible spectrum of MBPDE, HBPDE and HMBPD were predicted in different solvents using the time dependent TD-DFT [B3LYP/6-311+G(d,p)] method using Polarizable Continuum Model (PCM). The non-linear optical (NLO) properties were calcd. by M06 functional with the 6-311+G(d,p) basis set. A synergistic relationship is obsd. between the exptl. and theor. findings. NBO anal. provided insights about the stability and charge delocalization of the entitled mols. The global reactivity descriptors were achieved through HOMO-LUMO energies. The efficiency of the entitled mols. concerning charge transfer and participation in diverse chem. reactivities were figured out perceptibly by applying the frontier MOs (FMOs) anal. The av. polarizability <α> values: 277.184, 261.332 and 280.254 a.u. of the MBPDE, HBPDE and HMBPD were detd. resp. The total first hyperpolarizability (βtot) values of the MBPDE, HBPDE and HMBPD were also obtained to be 992.900, 781.527 and 1107.526 a.u. resp. The compd. HMBPD comprising of higher magnitude of av. polarizability and the total first hyperpolarizability (βtot) values than MBPDE and HBPDE mols. Moreover, NLO properties of urea mol. were found smaller in comparison to the MBPDE, HBPDE and HMBPD. The medicinal importance of these novel compds. as well as its contribution towards nonlinear optical field are our future targets.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      14. 14
        Ali, A.; Khalid, M.; Marrugo, K. P.; Kamal, G. M.; Saleem, M.; Khan, M. U.; Concepción, O.; de la Torre, A. F. Spectroscopic and DFT/TDDFT insights of the novel phosphonate imine compounds. J. Mol. Struct. 2020, 1207, 127838,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2020.127838

        14
        Spectroscopic and DFT/TDDFT insights of the novel phosphonate imine compounds
        Ali, Akbar; Khalid, Muhammad; Marrugo, Kelly P.; Kamal, Ghulam Mustafa; Saleem, Muhammad; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Concepcion, Odette; de la Torre, Alexander F.
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2020), 1207 (), 127838CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Recently, phosphonate compds. have got immense attention of the scientific community due to their structural properties. These are inserted in a no. of chem. moieties and are assocd. with important pharmacol. activities. Herein, we reported synthesis of the imino phosphonate compds.: (E)-di-Et (3-nitrobenzylideneamino)(phenyl)methylphosphonate (DNBMP), (E)-di-Et (4-hydroxybenzylideneamino) (phenyl) Me phosphonate (DHBMP), and (E)-di-Et (4-nitrobenzylideneamino)(phenyl)methylphosphonate (DNPMP) with high yields form the condensation reaction of di-Et (α-aminobenzyl)phosphonate hydrochloride and the corresponding substituted benzaldehyde. The synthesized compds. were analyzed by various spectroscopic techniques such as NMR, MS, UV-Vis, and IR spectroscopy. Moreover, the computational studies were also performed and the exptl. and theor. investigation results were compared. The geometries of the compds. were optimized with B3LYP/6-311+G (d,p) and absence of imaginary frequency confirmed the stability of DNBMP, DHBMP and DNPMP. The FT-IR, natural bond orbital (NBO) anal., frontier MOs (FMOs) and nonlinear (NLO) properties of DNBMP, DHBMP, and DNPMP were performed with former level of theory. In addn., UV-Vis spectra were obtained by Time Dependent D. Functional Theory (TD-DFT) approach with former level in Polarizable Continuum Model (PCM) using different solvents. A comparative investigation of FT-IR and UV-Visible spectra of DNBMP, DHBMP and DNPMP revealed that there is a good agreement between DFT and exptl. findings. NBO anal. was employed to calc. the at. charges as well as bonding interactions of the interesting mols. NBO findings revealed that non-bonding interactions might be one of the most important reasons for stability of DNBMP, DHBMP and DNPMP. Moreover, the energy value of HOMO/LUMO was found to be -6.977/-3.033 eV with ΔE 3.944 eV (DNBMP), -6.300/-1.274 eV with ΔE 5.026 eV (DHBMP) and -6.993/-3.124 eV with a band gap (ΔE) 3.869 eV (DNPMP) and global reactivity parameters (GRP) were also obtained using the HOMO-LUMO energies. It was obsd. that DNBMP, DHBMP and DNPMP have greater NLO responses than std. mols.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXjtFGlur0%253D&md5=e7c6473d0b18c28b4b9fd3792cbe4354
        open URL

        Malik, A. N.; Kuznetsov, A.; Ali, A.; Ashfaq, M.; Tahir, M. N.; Siddique, A. Imine-Based Zwitterion: Synthesis, Single-Crystal Characterization, and Computational Investigation. J. Mol. Struct. 2022, 1253, 132237,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2021.132237
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Imine-based Zwitterion: Synthesis, single-crystal characterization, and computational investigation
        Malik, Abida Naseem; Kuznetsov, Aleksey; Ali, Akbar; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Siddique, Abubakar
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2022), 1253 (), 132237CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The 2-hydroxy-1-naphthaldehyde based Schiff base zwitterions: (E)-1-(((4-methoxyphenyl)-iminio)methyl)naphthalen-2-olate (3a) and (E)-1-(((2-methoxy-4-nitrophenyl)iminio)methyl)-naphthalen-2-olate (3b) have been obtained from the condensation reaction of 2-hydroxy-1-naphthaldehyde and substituted aniline. The structures of these Schiff base zwitterions have been verified unambiguously by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction anal. The SC-XRD (single crystal X-ray diffraction) exploration revealed that both compds. have same crystal system, i.e., monoclinic, and same space group, i.e., P21/c. Also, there are intermol. attractive forces that are responsible for the stabilization of these org. frameworks. Addnl., these structures have been thoroughly explored by the d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. The optimized geometries were found to be close to the exptl. structures. The anal. of frontier MOs (FMOs) suggested that 3a would be more stable towards redox reactions than 3b. Therefore, modifying the imine-zwitterion structure with the nitro group and changing the position of methoxy group would increase the reactivity of the resulting species. This is further supported by the computed global reactivity parameters (GRPs): both compds. should be considered as noticeably stable, both from thermodn. and kinetic points of view, with 3a showing even higher stability. The compd. 3b was shown to be more reactive in redox processes, being more prone to be reduced rather than oxidized. The higher stability of 3a was further supported by the NBO anal. results.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB38XhslWjtQ%253D%253D&md5=de9c64b819541a8faa68fcf174f67cfb
        open URL

        Synthesis, X-ray crystal structure, thermal behavior and spectroscopic analysis of 1-(1-naphthoyl)-3-(halo-phenyl)-thioureas complemented with quantum chemical calculations
        Saeed, Aamer; Ashraf, Saba; White, Jonathan M.; Soria, Delia B.; Franca, Carlos A.; Erben, Mauricio F.
        Spectrochimica Acta, Part A: Molecular and Biomolecular Spectroscopy (2015), 150 (), 409-418CODEN: SAMCAS; ISSN:1386-1425. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Two novel 1-(1-naphthoyl)-3-(halo-phenyl) substituted thioureas, 1-(1-naphthoyl)-3-(2,4-di-fluoro-phenyl)-thiourea (1) and 1-(1-naphthoyl)-3-(3-chloro-4-fluoro-phenyl)-thiourea (2), were synthesized and fully characterized. The x-ray crystal and mol. structures were detd. resulting in a planar acylthiourea group, with the C=O and C=S adopting a pseudo-antiperiplanar conformation. An intramol. N-H···O=C hydrogen bond occurs between the thioamide and carbonyl groups. The crystal packing of both compds. is characterized by extended intermol. N-H···S=C and N-H···O=C hydrogen-bonding interactions involving the acylthiourea moiety. Compd. 2 is further stabilized by π-stacking between adjacent naphthalene and Ph rings. The thermal behavior, as well as the vibrational properties, studied by IR and Raman spectroscopy data complemented by quantum chem. calcns. at the B3PW91/6-311++G(d,p) support the formation of these intra- and intermol. hydrogen bonds. Also, the UV-visible spectrum is interpreted in terms of TD-DFT quantum chem. calcns. with the shapes of the simulated absorption spectra in good accordance with the exptl. data.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Saeed, A.; Erben, M. F.; Flörke, U. Effect of fluorine substitution on the crystal structures and vibrational properties of phenylthiourea isomers. J. Mol. Struct. 2010, 982, 91– 99,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2010.08.012

        18
        Effect of fluorine substitution on the crystal structures and vibrational properties of phenylthiourea isomers
        Saeed, Aamer; Erben, Mauricio F.; Floerke, Ulrich
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2010), 982 (1-3), 91-99CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The 1-(2-chlorobenzoyl)-3-(isomeric fluorophenyl)thiourea derivs. (1-3) were prepd. by the reaction of 2-chlorobenzoyl isothiocyanate produced in situ with isomeric fluoroanilines in excellent yields. The novel compds. are characterized by multinuclear (1H and 13C) NMR, GC-MS, elemental analyses and FTIR spectroscopy techniques. Structural and conformational properties of compds. 1-3 are analyzed using a combined approach including X-ray diffraction, vibrational spectra (solid FTIR and FT-Raman) and theor. calcn. methods. The crystal structures have been detd. by X-ray diffraction methods. The three species crystallize in the monoclinic C2/c space group with Z = 8 mols. per unit cell. The carbonyl and thiourea groups are almost planar and the conformation adopted by the C=S and the C=O double bonds is antiperiplanar. The crystal lattices show the presence of centrosym. dimeric units held by N-H···S hydrogen bonds stacked along the [0 1 0] plane. The effect of fluorine substitution on the vibrational properties and on the conformational space has been detd. by quantum chem. calcns. (B3LYP functional in connection with the 6-311+G* basis sets) and vibrational spectroscopy.

        (E)-4-Methoxy-2-[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyliminomethyl]phenol
        Kelesoglu, Zeynep; Buyukgungor, Orhan; Albayrak, Cigdem; Odabasoglu, Mustafa
        Acta Crystallographica, Section E: Structure Reports Online (2009), 65 (12), o3245-o3246CODEN: ACSEBH; ISSN:1600-5368. (International Union of Crystallography)
        (E)-4-Methoxy-2-[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyliminomethyl]phenol, C15H12F3NO2, adopts the phenol-imine tautomeric form, with the H atom attached to O rather than to N. There are 2 independent mols. aligned nearly parallel in the asym. unit with their trifluoromethyl groups pointing in opposite directions. The dihedral angles between the arom. rings are 40.43(1)° in the 1st mol. and 36.12(1)° in the 2nd. Strong intramol. O-H···N H bonding generates S(6) ring motifs. Weak intermol. C-H···O H bonds link the independent mols. sep. into sheets normal to [010]. C-H···π interactions are also obsd. The F atoms of the trifluoromethyl groups are disordered over 2 sets of sites with refined site occupancies of 0.59(2)/0.41(2) and 0.62(3)/0.38(3), resp. Crystallog. data are given.

        In the title compd., C14H10F3NO2, the two benzene rings are oriented at a dihedral angle of 31.94(14)°. An intramol. O-H...N H bond helps to stabilize the mol. structure. In the crystal, intermol. O-H...O H bonding links the mols., forming chains running along the crystallog. a axis. The F atoms of the trifluoromethyl group are disordered over two positions with refined site occupancies of 0.488(5) and 0.512(5). Crystallog. data and at. coordinates are given.

        The title Schiff base compd., 0.57C17H12FNO·0.43C17H12FNO, reveals both the enol (OH) and keto (NH) tautomeric forms with occupancies of 0.57 (6) and 0.43 (6), resp. The tautomeric forms are stabilized by intramol. O-H...N (enol) and N-H...O (keto) hydrogen bonds. The dihedral angle between the naphthalene ring system and the benzene ring is 32.76 (1)°. Crystallog. data are given.

        The investigation of nonlinear optical properties of N-(3-fluorophenyl)naphthaldimine
        Uenver, H.; Karakas, A.; Elmali, A.; Durlu, T. N.
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2005), 737 (2-3), 131-137CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        N-(3-Fluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-1-naphthaldimine (I) has been synthesized. The phys. properties and structure of I have been characterized by X-ray diffraction anal., elemental anal., and FT-IR, 1H-NMR, and UV-visible spectroscopies. It is found that I has solvatochromic behavior in the UV and visible regions, implying non-zero microscopic first hyperpolarizability. The elec. dipole moment (μ) and the first hyperpolarizability (β) values of I have been computed using ab initio quantum mech. calcns. (finite field second-order Moller-Plesset perturbation theory). The calcn. results also reveal that I might have microscopic nonlinear optical behavior with non-zero values.

        (a) Spackman, M. A.; Jayatilaka, D. Hirshfeld surface analysis. CrystEngComm 2009, 11, 19– 32,  DOI: 10.1039/b818330a

        26a
        Hirshfeld surface analysis
        Spackman, Mark A.; Jayatilaka, Dylan
        CrystEngComm (2009), 11 (1), 19-32CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. In the last few years the anal. of mol. crystal structures using tools based on Hirshfeld surfaces has rapidly gained in popularity. This approach represents an attempt to venture beyond the current paradigm-internuclear distances and angles, crystal packing diagrams with mols. represented via various models, and the identification of close contacts deemed to be important-and to view mols. as org. wholes, thereby fundamentally altering the discussion of intermol. interactions through an unbiased identification of all close contacts.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVCksg%253D%253D&md5=8ea7ce8d0092ecef6d1ef9477f7cf0b4
        open URL
        .
        (b) Tahir, M. N.; Ashfaq, M.; De la Torre, A. F.; Caballero, J.; Hernández-Rodríguez, E. W.; Ali, A. Rationalizing the stability and interactions of 2,4-diamino-5-(4-chlorophenyl)-6-ethylpyrimidin-1-ium 2-hydroxy-3,5-dinitrobenzoate salt. J. Mol. Struct. 2019, 1193, 185– 194,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2019.05.003
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26b
        Rationalizing the stability and interactions of 2,4-diamino-5-(4-chlorophenyl)-6-ethylpyrimidin-1-ium 2-hydroxy-3,5-dinitrobenzoate salt
        Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Ashfaq, Muhammad; de la Torre, Alexander F.; Caballero, Julio; Hernandez-Rodriguez, Erix W.; Ali, Akbar
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2019), 1193 (), 185-194CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The crystal structure of the salt produced by the reaction of pyrimethamine (an antimalarial drug) with 2-hydroxy-3,5-dinitrobenzoic acid [systematic name: 2,4-diamino-5-(4-chlorophenyl)-6-ethylpyrimidin-1-ium 2-hydroxy-3,5-dinitrobenzoate] has been investigated using X-rays diffraction data collected at room temp. The results showed that there are strong intermol. C-H···O, N-H···N, O-H···O types of hydrogen bonding interactions that play a key role in the crystal structure stabilization while C-H···O and C-H ... π interaction further stabilize the structure. In addn., theor. calcns. were done to compute the binding free energies and the electron densities assocd. to heterodimeric, heterotrimeric and heterotetrameric salt assemblies of the pyrimethamine-2-hydroxy-3,5-dinitrobenzoate salt. The mol. electron densities, electrostatic potential and the regions of electron d. accumulation as well as depletion were explored for these assemblies. These analyses not only suggest the high salt stability but also appropriate electrostatic properties of the pyrimethamine drug for the interaction with a carboxylic group that is attached to the side chains of glutamate and aspartate residues in proteins.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXpvFeks78%253D&md5=6e4927f0aa3a3a2f30740b079aff4210

        26c
        Stabilization of Supramolecular Assembly of N-Substituted Benzylidene Acetohydrazide Analogs by Non-Covalent Interactions: A Concise Experimental and Theoretical Approach
        Khalid, Muhammad; Ali, Akbar; Tariq, Jahrukh; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Aliabad, Hossein Asghar Rahnamaye; Hussain, Ishtiaq; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Khan, Muhammad Usman
        ChemistrySelect (2020), 5 (34), 10618-10631CODEN: CHEMUD; ISSN:2365-6549. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Herein, the cryst. N-substituted benzylidene acetohydrazide derivs.: N'-(4-bromo-2-fluorobenzylidene)-2-((6-chloropyridin-2-yl)oxy) acetohydrazide (BFBAH) and 2-((6-chloropyridin-2-yl)oxy)-N'-(4-methoxybenzylidene) acetohydrazide (MOBAH) were produced and the structures were characterized and confirmed by the NMR spectroscopy and single crystal anal. SC-XRD study disclosed that the mols. are connected with each other in the form of dimers through hydrogen bonding in the cryst. network of BFBAH and MOBAH. Addnl., the theor. calcns. were performed using the DFT/B3LYP/6-311G(d,p) functional. The hyperconjugation and intermol. hydrogen bonding were explored by using NBO anal. Hirshfeld surface anal. analyzing intra and intermol. interactions, uncovered that supramol. assemblies have been stabilized by N-H···O and C-H···O intermol. hydrogen bonds, as well as van der Waals interactions. The quantum theory of atoms in mols. (QT-AIM) study corroborates that both significant N-H···O and C-H···O H-bonds are strong in nature. Besides, global reactivity indexes were computed via the energies of HOMO and LUMO orbitals.

DFT and single crystal analysis of the pyrimethamine-based novel co-crystal salt: 2,4-diamino-5-(4-chloro-phenyl)-6-ethylpyrimidin-1-ium:4-hydroxybenzoate:methanol:hydrate (1:1:1:1) (DEHMH). J. Mol.         26d
        DFT and single crystal analysis of the pyrimethamine-based novel co-crystal salt: 2,4-diamino-5-(4-chloro-phenyl)-6-ethylpyrimidin-1-ium:4-hydroxybenzoate:methanol:hydrate (1:1:1:1) (DEHMH)
        Ashfaq, Muhammad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Kuznetsov, Aleksey; Mirza, Shafaat Hussain; Khalid, Muhammad; Ali, Akbar
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2020), 1199 (), 127041CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The present work is related to the synthesis, single crystal anal., and computational investigation of pyrimethamine co-crystal salt with 4-hydroxybenzoic acid in methanol. The study shows that hydrogen bonding interactions are responsible for the stabilized 3-dimensional network. In the title compd., protonation of the pyrimethamine mol. results in the more basic nitrogen atom present in the 1,3-diazine ring to form a cation which interacts with the carboxylate (the conjugate base) of 4-hydroxybenzoic acid. Moreover, the computational study including analyses of charge distribution, frontier MOs, reactivity parameters, and mol. electrostatic potential has been also performed for this compd. Both the exptl. and computational results showed the formation of intermol. hydrogen bonding and electrostatic interactions that suggest the increased reactivity and potential biol. activity of the compd. The current compd. can have potential future applications in pharmacol. for the prodn. of new antimalarial drugs.

        26e
        Recurrent π-π stacking motifs in three new 4,5-dihydropyrazolyl-thiazole-coumarin hybrids: X-ray characterization, Hirshfeld surface analysis and DFT calculations
        Madni, Murtaza; Ahmed, Muhammad Naeem; Hafeez, Muhammad; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Gil, Diego M.; Galmes, Bartomeu; Hameed, Shahid; Frontera, Antonio
        New Journal of Chemistry (2020), 44 (34), 14592-14603CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The synthesis and X-ray characterization of three new 4,5-dihydropyrazolylthiazole-coumarin hybrids (1-3) are reported herein, namely 3-(2-(3,5-bis(4-chlorophenyl)-4,5-dihydropyrazol-1-yl)thiazol-4-yl)-2H-chromen-2-one (1), 3-(2-(5-(4-chlorophenyl)-4,5-dihydro-3-phenylpyrazol-1-yl)thiazol-4-yl)-2H-chromen-2-one (2) and 3-(2-(3-(4-chlorophenyl)-4,5-dihydro-5-p-tolylpyrazol-1-yl)thiazol-4-yl)-2H-chromen-2-one (3). A detailed structural anal. of the noncovalent interactions and their evaluation using Hirshfeld surface anal. is also reported, evidencing the importance of C-H···O and π-π interactions. Finally, DFT calcns. along with the mol. electrostatic potential (MEP) and NCIplot index anal. have been used to evaluate those interactions energetically and to investigate the relative importance of two different π-stacking modes that are recurrent binding motifs in the solid state architecture of the three complexes.

        27a
        Supramolecular self-assembly of a coumarine-based acylthiourea synthon directed by π-stacking interactions: Crystal structure and Hirshfeld surface analysis
        Saeed, Aamer; Ashraf, Saba; Florke, Ulrich; Delgado Espinoza, Zuly Yuliana; Erben, Mauricio F.; Perez, Hiram
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2016), 1111 (), 76-83CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The structure of 1-(2-oxo-2H-chromene-3-carbonyl)-3-(2-methoxy-phenyl)thiourea (1) has been detd. by single-crystal X-ray crystallog. This compd. crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with a = 7.455 (2) Å, b = 12.744 (3) Å, c = 16.892 (4) Å, β = 90.203 (6)° and Z = 4. Both, the coumarin and the Ph rings are nearly coplanar with the central 1-acylthiourea group, with the C=O and C=S bonds adopting an opposite orientation. Intramol. N-H···O, C-H···O, and C-H···S hydrogen bonds are favored by the planar conformation. The mols. are packed through C-H···O, C-H···S and C-H···C hydrogen bonds, and two π···π interactions with offset arrangement. Inter-centroid distance of 3.490 (2) Å, slip angles of 18.5 and 20.9°, and vertical displacements of 1.10 and 1.24 Å are the stacking parameters corresponding to the stronger π···π interaction. Hirshfeld surface anal. was performed for visualizing, exploring and quantifying intermol. interactions in the crystal lattice of compd. 1, and compared with two closely related species. Shape index and Curvedness surfaces indicated π-stacking with different features in opposed sides of the mol. Fingerprint plot showed C···C contacts with similar contributions to the crystal packing in comparison with those assocd. to hydrogen bonds. Enrichment ratios for H···H, O···H, S···H and C···C contacts revealed a high propensity to form in the crystal.

        Synthesis, crystal structure, Hirshfeld surface analysis, spectroscopic characterizations and electrical properties of the new complex of cobalt (III) and the Schiff-base of dihydroxycoumarin
        Ketata, Imen; Bejaoui, Linda; Brahmia, Ameni; Ben Hassen, Rached
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1246 (), 131161CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A new cobalt(III) complex, the [3,3'-{ethane-1,2-diylbis[(azanylylidene)eth-1-yl-1-ylidene]}bis [4-(hydroxy)-2H-1-benzopyran-2-onato]]-[bis(pyridine)]-cobalt chloradioxirane-1,1-dione hydrate, promising for its fluorescent and elec. properties was synthesized by the reaction of the Schiff-base '4-hydroxy-3-((E)-1-(2-((E)-1-(4-hydroxy-2-oxo-2H-chromen-3-yl)ethylideneamino)ethylimino)ethyl)-2H-chromene-2-one' and cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate under an oxygen-rich atm. The structure was detd. by single crystal x-ray diffraction and confirmed by FTIR and UV-visible spectroscopies. Hirshfeld's surface anal. indicates that the most important inter-mol. hydrogen bond within crystal packing is O-H···O interaction and the presence of a π-π stack was evident by the shape index and the curvature. It was also characterized for its high green emission in polar aprotic solvents using spectrofluorometry. Dielec. const. (ε'), dielec. loss (tan δ) and cond. (σ) were studied as a function of temp. and frequency. The results could be very significant in electronic and optoelectronic device applications.

        Green synthesis, SC-XRD, non-covalent interactive potential and electronic communication via DFT exploration of pyridine-based hydrazone
        Ali, Akbar; Khalid, Muhammad; Abid, Saba; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Iqbal, Javed; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Kanwal, Fariha; Lu, Changrui; ur Rehman, Muhammad Fayyaz
        Crystals (2020), 10 (9), 778CODEN: CRYSBC; ISSN:2073-4352. (MDPI AG)
        This study presents the sonochem. fabrication and characterization of a pyridine-based halogenated hydrazone, (E)-2-((6-chloropyridin-2-yl)oxy)-N'-(2-hydroxybenzylidene)acetohydrazide (HBPAH). The NMR spectroscopic technique was used to det. the structure, while SC-XRD confirmed its cryst. nature. Structural studies revealed that strong, inter-mol. attractive forces stabilize this cryst. org. compd. Moreover, the compd. was optimized at the B3LYP/6-311G(d,p) level using the Crystallog. Information File (CIF). Natural bonding orbital (NBO) and natural population anal. (NPA) were performed at the same level using optimized geometry. Time-dependent d. functional theory (DFT) was performed at the B3LYP/6-311G (d,p) method to calc. the frontier MOs (FMOs) and mol. electrostatic potential (MEP). The global reactivity descriptors were detd. using HOMO and LUMO energy gaps. Theor. calcns. based on the Quantum Theory of Atoms in Mols. (QT-AIM) and Hirshfeld analyses identified the non-covalent and covalent interactions of the HBPAH compd. Consequently, QT-AIM and Hirshfeld analyses agree with exptl. results.

        29c
        O-4-Acetylamino-benzenesulfonylated pyrimidine derivatives: synthesis, SC-XRD, DFT analysis and electronic behaviour investigation
        Khalid, Muhammad; Ali, Akbar; Haq, Sadia; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Iqbal, Javed; Braga, Ataualpa A. C.; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Akhtar, Samee Ul Hassan
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1224 (), 129308CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Beginning with 2-amino-6-methyl-pyrimidin-4-ol and 2,6-diamino-pyrimidin-4-ol, 2-amino-6-methylpyrimidin-4-yl 4-acetamidobenzenesulfonate (APABS) and 2,6-diaminopyrimidin-4-yl 4-acetamidobenzenesulfonate (DPACS) were synthesized resp. through O-4-acetylamino-benzenesulfonylation reaction. The structures of the (APABS) and (DPACS) were verified unambiguously by the single crystal X-ray diffraction technique. The X-ray diffraction inspection inferred that these chem. architectures are stabilized by intermol. attractive forces. The quantum chem. examn. of optimized geometry, vibrational anal. and natural bond orbitals (NBOs) properties for APABS and DPACS were attained by adopting B3LYP/6-311G(d,p) level. Moreover, the frontier MOs (FMOs) anal. was detd. by TD-DFT/B3LYP/ 6-311G(d,p) level. The simulated structural parameters and XRD results of APABS and DPACS were found in close agreement to that of concerned exptl. findings. The mol. stability owing to strongest hyperconjugative interactions in APABS and DPACS was evaluated through NBO investigation. The transfer of charge phenomenon in the entitled compds. was evaluated by FMOs. The increasing order of energy gap for compds. is APABS<DPACS. Frontier MO energies of entitled compds. are also used to calc. the global reactivity indexes. The engagement of various sites in terms of chem. reactivities was detd. by mol. electrosatic potential anal. Moreover, Hirshfeld surfaces were studied which supported the X-ray diffraction investigation in terms of intermol. attractive forces.

        29d
        Single crystal investigation, Hirshfeld surface analysis and DFT exploration of the pyrimethamine-based novel organic salt: 2,4-diamino-5-(4-chlorophenyl)-6-ethylpyrimidin-1-ium 3-carboxybenzoate hydrate (1:1:1)
        Ashfaq, Muhammad; Bogdanov, Georgii; Glebov, Viktor; Ali, Akbar; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Abdullah, Safia
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1224 (), 129309CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        In current research work, synthesis of pyrimethamine-based novel org. salt: 2,4-diamino-5-(4-chlorophenyl)-6-ethylpyrimidin-1-ium 3-carboxybenzoate hydrate (1:1:1) (DECH) was reported. The org. salt was synthesized from acid base reaction of pyrimethamine and isophthalic acid. The structure of accomplished DECH was verified unambiguously by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD) anal. The SC-XRD investigation showed that anion and cation counterparts of org. salt form infinite 2D network due to N-H···O, C-H···O and O-H···O bonding. The weak interaction of type C-O···π was also assisting strengthening of crystal lattice of DECH. The mol. geometry of compd. in ground state was calcd. by using d. functional theory (DFT) method with 6-311++G(d,p) basis set and were compared with exptl. data. Addnl., HOMO-LUMO energy gap and mol. electrostatic potential (MEP) properties of compd. were performed at B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) level. Hirshfeld surface anal. of investigated DECH was used to confirm existence, strength and order of intermol. interactions in compd. The title org. salt appeared to be stable high reactive nucleophile.

        30
        Intermolecular interactions in crystalline 1-(adamantane-1-carbonyl)-3-substituted thioureas with Hirshfeld surface analysis
        Saeed, Aamer; Bolte, Michael; Erben, Mauricio F.; Perez, Hiram
        CrystEngComm (2015), 17 (39), 7551-7563CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The conformationally congested species 1-(adamantane-1-carbonyl)-3-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)thiourea has been prepd. and fully characterized by elemental analyses, FTIR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and mass spectrometry. Its crystal structure was detd. by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The dihedral angle between the plane of the 2,4,6-trimethylphenyl group and the plane of the thiourea fragment was optimized by theor. calcns. applying the B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) level for the purpose of investigating the conformational effects on the stabilization of the crystal packing. A detailed anal. of the intermol. interactions in a series of six closely related phenylthiourea species bearing the 1-(adamantane-1-carbonyl) group has been performed based on the Hirshfeld surfaces and their assocd. two-dimensional fingerprint plots. The relative contributions of the main intermol. contacts as well as the enrichment ratios derived from the Hirshfeld surface anal. establish the 1-acyl thiourea synthon to be a widespread contributor.

        31
        Structural Characterization, DFT, Hirshfeld Surface Analysis and Antibacterial Activity of a Schiff Base Derived from Cyclohexanediamine
        Nasaruddin, Nur Husnina; Ahmad, Shahrul Nizam; Sirat, Siti Syaida; Wai, Tan Kong; Zakaria, Nurul Aili; Bahron, Hadariah
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1232 (), 130066CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A new Schiff base derived from cyclohexanediamine and 3-methylsalicylaldehyde was obtained. The Schiff base, 6,6'-((1E,1'E)-(cyclohexane-1,2-diylbis(azanylylidene))bis(methanylylidene))bis(2-methylphenol), (AD2Me) was characterized through elemental anal., IR, UV-Vis, 1H and 13C NMR (NMR) spectroscopy. The structure of the grown crystal was elucidated by using single crystal X-ray diffraction technique. The compd. crystd. in the triclinic system, P-1 space group. The cell length and vol. for AD2Me are a = 10.4582(11) Å, b =10.8141(9) Å, c =18.7472(14) Å, α = 90.629(7)°, β = 92.444(7)°, γ = 109.561(9)° and V =1995.3(3) Å3, resp. The crystal structure is stabilized by intramol. hydrogen bond OH•••N and intermol. hydrogen bonds CH•••O, CH•••π and π•••π. The B3LYP method was used to calc. the optimized structure of the mol. through d. functional theory (DFT) using the 6-311G++(d, p) basis set and the results of the conformation anal. was in good agreement with the crystal structure detd. by x-ray single crystal diffraction. Addnl., the mol. electrostatic potential, frontier MOs and chem. reactivity descriptors of AD2Me were further investigated using DFT, revealing the electronic properties of the compd. A Hirshfeld surface anal. was performed to analyze intermol. interactions in the crystal structure. The compd. showed no significant activity against Staphylococcus aureus subsp. aureus Rosenbach (ATCC 6538) and Streptococcus mutans Clarke (ATCC 700610).

Intermolecular interactions in antipyrine-like derivatives 2-halo-N-(1,5-dimethyl-3-oxo-2-phenyl-2,3-dihydro-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzamides: X-ray structure, Hirshfeld surface analysis and DFT calculations.         32
        Intermolecular interactions in antipyrine-like derivatives 2-halo-N-(1,5-dimethyl-3-oxo-2-phenyl-2,3-dihydro-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzamides: X-ray structure, Hirshfeld surface analysis and DFT calculations
        Saeed, Aamer; Khurshid, Asma; Florke, Ulrich; Echeverria, Gustavo A.; Piro, Oscar E.; Gil, Diego M.; Rocha, Mariana; Frontera, Antonio; El-Seedi, Hesham R.; Mumtaz, Amara; Erben, Mauricio F.
        New Journal of Chemistry (2020), 44 (45), 19541-19554CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The synthesis, X-ray structure characterization, Hirshfeld surface anal. and DFT calcns. of two new antipyrine derivs. are reported herein. Particularly, 2-bromo-N-(2,3-dihydro-1,5-dimethyl-3-oxo-2-phenyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzamide (1) and 2-chloro-N-(2,3-dihydro-1,5-dimethyl-3-oxo-2-phenyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzamide (2) are synthesized in good yields and characterized spectroscopically. Both compds. are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic P21/c space group. The crystal packing of both compds. is mainly stabilized by a combination of N-H···O and C-H···O hydrogen bonds. In addn., C-H···π and lone pair···π contacts were obsd. Their solid-state structures have been analyzed through Hirshfeld surface anal., including the evaluation of the different energy frameworks, indicating that the mol. sheets are primarily formed by hydrogen bonds and the stabilization is dominated via the electrostatic energy contribution. These studies are complemented with DFT calcns. (B3LYP-D3/def2-TZVP), and a combination of QTAIM/NCIplot analyses disclosing that the H-bonding interactions are energetically relevant (ranging from 0.9 to 6.1 kcal mol-1), however the total binding energies of the different assemblies are dominated by a combination of π-interactions (of the type C-H···π, π···π, and lone pair halogen···π) that are able to stabilize cooperatively the assemblies up to 12 kcal mol-1.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXitFGlsLzM&md5=023a902ef22391f55f69e4c9dbaced8c
        open URL
      33. 33
        Jelsch, C.; Ejsmont, K.; Huder, L. The enrichment ratio of atomic contacts in crystals, an indicator derived from the Hirshfeld surface analysis. IUCrJ 2014, 1, 119– 128,  DOI: 10.1107/s2052252514003327
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        The enrichment ratio of atomic contacts in crystals, an indicator derived from the Hirshfeld surface analysis
        Jelsch, Christian; Ejsmont, Krzysztof; Huder, Loic
        IUCrJ (2014), 1 (2), 119-128CODEN: IUCRAJ; ISSN:2052-2525. (International Union of Crystallography)
        The partitioning of space with Hirshfeld surfaces enables the anal. of fingerprint mol. interactions in cryst. environments. This study uses the decompn. of the crystal contact surface between pairs of interacting chem. species to derive an enrichment ratio. This quantity enables the anal. of the propensity of chem. species to form intermol. interactions with themselves and other species. The enrichment ratio is obtained by comparing the actual contacts in the crystal with those computed as if all types of contacts had the same probability to form. The enrichments and contact tendencies were analyzed in several families of compds., based on chem. compn. and arom. character. As expected, the polar contacts of the type H···N, H···O and H···S, which are generally hydrogen bonds, show enrichment values larger than unity. O···O and N···N contacts are impoverished while H···H interactions display enrichment ratios which are generally close to unity or slightly lower. In arom. compds., C···C contacts can display large enrichment ratios due to extensive π···π stacking in the crystal packings of heterocyclic compds. C···C contacts are, however, less enriched in pure (C,H) hydrocarbons as π···π stacking is not so favorable from the electrostatic point of view compared with heterocycles. C···H contacts are favored in (C,H) aroms., but these interactions occur less in compds. contg. O, N or S as some H atoms are then involved in hydrogen bonds. The study also highlights the fact that hydrogen is a prefered interaction partner for fluorine.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXns1WhsL4%253D&md5=c158e85c14d08fd8faea094094582bc9
        open URL
      34. 34
        (a) Ali, A.; Kuznetsov, A.; Khan, M. U.; Tahir, M. N.; Ashfaq, M.; Raza, A. R.; Muhammad, S. 2-Amino-6-methylpyridine based co-crystal salt formation using succinic acid: Single-crystal analysis and computational exploration. J. Mol. Struct. 2021, 1230, 129893,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2021.129893
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34a
        2-Amino-6-methylpyridine based co-crystal salt formation using succinic acid: Single-crystal analysis and computational exploration
        Ali, Akbar; Kuznetsov, Aleksey; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Raza, Abdul Rauf; Muhammad, Shabbir
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1230 (), 129893CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The current work reports the formation methodol. of the co-crystal between 2-amino-6-methylpyridine and succinic acid, its single-crystal characterization, and the computational study. The single-crystal anal. showed that the co-crystal mols. are interlinked by N···H-O and O···H-O bonds to form R22(8) loop and D22(5) and D22(8) finite pattern along with the formation of infinite 2D network in the (101) plane having base vectors [101] and [010]. The weak interactions of the π-π stacking type and C-O-Cg interactions are found in the title compd. helping in further strengthening of the crystal structure. The Hirshfeld surface anal. confirmed that H···H interat. contacts are the largest contributor to entire interat. contacts with contribution of 45.8%. The computational studies supported the presence of significantly strong H bonds within the title complex. The MO anal. suggested that both HOMO/HOMO-1 and LUMO/LUMO+1 would be able to participate in oxidative-reductive processes of the complex. The HOMO has dominating contributions from 1 succinate unit along with minor contributions from the H-bonded NH2-group of the neighboring 2-amino-6-methylpyridin-1-ium moiety. The calcd. values of the global reactivity parameters suggest noticeable stability of the title complex. It possesses quite pronounced nonlinear optical properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXhvVSltr0%253D&md5=d807a7e838eb5a5e4615c27fdb801be2
        open URL

        (b) Ali, A.; Khalid, M.; Tahir, M. N.; Imran, M.; Ashfaq, M.; Hussain, R.; Assiri, M. A.; Khan, I. Synthesis of Diaminopyrimidine Sulfonate Derivatives and Exploration of Their Structural and Quantum Chemical Insights via SC-XRD and the DFT Approach. ACS Omega 2021, 6, 7047– 7057,  DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.0c06323
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34b
        Synthesis of Diaminopyrimidine Sulfonate Derivatives and Exploration of Their Structural and Quantum Chemical Insights via SC-XRD and the DFT Approach
        Ali, Akbar; Khalid, Muhammad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Imran, Muhammad; Ashfaq, Muhammad; Hussain, Riaz; Assiri, Mohammed A.; Khan, Imran
        ACS Omega (2021), 6 (10), 7047-7057CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
        Two heterocyclic compds. named 2,6-diaminopyrimidin-4-ylnaphthalene-2-sulfonate (A) and 2,6-diaminopyrimidin-4-yl4-methylbenzene sulfonate (B) were synthesized. The structures of heterocyclic mols. were established by the X-ray crystallog. technique, which showed several noncovalent interactions as N···H···N, N···H···O, and C-H···O bonding and parallel offset stacking interaction. Hydrogen-bonding interactions were further explored by the Hirshfeld surface (HS) anal. Nonlinear optical (NLO) and natural bond orbital (NBO) properties were calcd. utilizing the B3LYP/6-311G(d,p) level. Frontier MOs (FMOs) and mol. electrostatic potential (MEP) were calcd. utilizing the time-dependent d. functional theory (TD-DFT) at the same level. The NBO anal. showed that the mol. stabilities of compds. A and B were attributed to their large stabilization energy values. The second hyperpolarizability (γtot) values for A and B were obtained as 3.7 x 104 and 2.7 x 104 au, resp. The exptl. X-ray crystallog. and theor. structural parameters of A and B were found to be in close correspondence. Both the mols. reveal substantial NLO responses that can be significant for their utilization in advanced applications.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXlsVCitbo%253D&md5=6ba4eacae51ebb52ec914486615d0522

        (a) Turner, M. J.; McKinnon, J. J.; Jayatilaka, D.; Spackman, M. A. Visualisation and characterisation of voids in crystalline materials. CrystEngComm 2011, 13, 1804– 1813,  DOI: 10.1039/c0ce00683a
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35a
        Visualisation and characterisation of voids in crystalline materials
        Turner, Michael J.; McKinnon, Joshua J.; Jayatilaka, Dylan; Spackman, Mark A.
        CrystEngComm (2011), 13 (6), 1804-1813CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A method of mapping void space by rolling a probe sphere of variable radius over a fused-sphere representation of a mol. crystal has been developed. Based on isosurfaces of the procrystal electron d., this approach can be used to locate and visualize the void space in cryst. materials, as well as compute surface areas and vols. of the voids. The method is capable of locating and characterizing all "empty" space, and not just the larger cavities and channels, in mol. crystals, org., metal-org. and inorg. polymers. Comparison is made with existing computational methods, as well as with the results from exptl. techniques that provide ests. of vols. and surface areas of void space and porosity.

        open URL

        (b) Ashfaq, M.; Tahir, M. N.; Muhammad, S.; Munawar, K. S.; Ali, A.; Bogdanov, G.; Alarfaji, S. S. Single-Crystal Investigation, Hirshfeld Surface Analysis, and DFT Study of Third-Order NLO Properties of Unsymmetrical Acyl Thiourea Derivatives. ACS Omega 2021, 6, 31211– 31225,  DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.1c04884
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35b
        Single-Crystal Investigation, Hirshfeld Surface Analysis, and DFT Study of Third-Order NLO Properties of Unsymmetrical Acyl Thiourea Derivatives
        Ashfaq, Muhammad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Muhammad, Shabbir; Munawar, Khurram Shahzad; Ali, Akbar; Bogdanov, Georgii; Alarfaji, Saleh S.
        ACS Omega (2021), 6 (46), 31211-31225CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
        In the current research work, unsym. acyl thiourea derivs., 4-((3-benzoylthioureido)methyl)cyclohexane-1-carboxylic acid (BTCC) and Me 2-(3-benzoylthioureido)benzoate (MBTB), have been synthesized efficiently. The structures of these cryst. thioureas were unambiguously confirmed by single-crystal diffractional anal. The crystallog. investigation showed that the mol. configuration of both compds. is stabilized by intramol. N-H···O bonding. The crystal packing of BTCC is stabilized by strong N-H···O bonding and comparatively weak O-H···S, C-H···O, C-H···π, and C-O···π interactions, whereas strong N-H···O bonding and comparatively weak C-H···O, C-H···S, and C-H···π interactions are responsible for the crystal packing of MBTB. The noncovalent interactions that are responsible for the crystal packing are explored by the Hirshfeld surface anal. for both compds. The void anal. is performed to find the quant. strength of crystal packing in both compds. Addnl., state-of-the-art applied quantum chem. techniques are used to further explore the structure-property relationship in the above-entitled mols. The optimization of mol. geometries showed a reasonably good correlation with their resp. exptl. structures. Third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) polarizability calcns. were performed to see the advanced functional application of entitled compds. as efficient NLO materials. The av. static γ amplitudes are found to be 27.30 x 10-36 and 102.91 x 10-36 esu for the compds. BTCC and MBTB, resp. The γ amplitude of MBTB is calcd. to be 3.77 times larger, which is probably due to better charge-transfer characteristics in MBTB. The quantum chem. anal. in the form of 3-D plots was also performed for their frontier MOs and mol. electrostatic potentials for understanding charge-transfer characteristics. We believe that the current investigation will not only report the new BTCC and MBTB compds. but also evoke the interest of the materials science community in their potential use in NLO applications.

        35c
        Synthesis, Crystal Structure, Hirshfeld Surface Analysis, and Computational Study of a Novel Organic Salt Obtained from Benzylamine and an Acidic Component
        Ashfaq, Muhammad; Munawar, Khurram Shahzad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Dege, Necmi; Yaman, Mavise; Muhammad, Shabbir; Alarfaji, Saleh S.; Kargar, Hadi; Arshad, Muhammad Umar
        ACS Omega (2021), 6 (34), 22357-22366CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
        A novel Schiff base compd. named as phenylmethanaminium (E)-4-((benzylimino)methyl)benzoate C7H10N+.C15H12NO2- (A) is synthesized by the chem. reaction of benzylamine and 4-carboxybenzaldehyde in ethanol, and the structure of the titled compd. is verified using the single-crystal X-ray diffraction technique. Structural investigation inferred that the crystal packing is mainly stabilized by N-H···O and comparatively weak C-H···O bonding between the cation and anion and further stabilized by weak C-H···π and C-O···π interactions. Hirshfeld surface anal. is employed to explore the noncovalent interactions that are responsible for crystal packing quant. Furthermore, we have used state-of-the-art quantum chem. calcns. to get comprehensive insights into the structure-optoelectronic property relationship for the entitled compd. The mol. geometry of compd. A is optimized at the M06/6-311G* level of theory. The linear polarizability, third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) polarizability, total and partial d. of states, and UV-visible spectrum are calcd. through quantum chem. calcns. We believe that compd. A is not only a new addn. to crystallog. data but also possesses good optical and NLO properties for its potential use in lasers and frequency-converting applications.

        (a) Braga, A. A. C.; Ujaque, G.; Maseras, F. A DFT Study of the Full Catalytic Cycle of the Suzuki–Miyaura Cross-Coupling on a Model System. Organometallics 2006, 25, 3647– 3658,  DOI: 10.1021/om060380i
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37a
        A DFT Study of the Full Catalytic Cycle of the Suzuki-Miyaura Cross-Coupling on a Model System
        Braga, Ataualpa A. C.; Ujaque, Gregori; Maseras, Feliu
        Organometallics (2006), 25 (15), 3647-3658CODEN: ORGND7; ISSN:0276-7333. (American Chemical Society)
        A computational study with the Becke3LYP DFT functional is carried out on the cross-coupling reaction of vinyl bromide, H2C:CHBr and vinylboronic acid, H2C:CHB(OH)2 catalyzed by Pd diphosphine [Pd(PH3)2] in the presence of an excess of OH- base. The full catalytic cycle is computed, starting from the sepd. reactants and the catalyst and finishing with the cross-coupled product and the regeneration of the catalyst. The different stages in the cycle (oxidative addn., isomerization, transmetalation, reductive elimination) were characterized through calcn. of the corresponding intermediates and transition states. Different alternative mechanisms are considered, depending on the no. of phosphine ligands at Pd, and on the cis or trans isomery around the metal center. The results indicate the existence of a no. of competitive pathways of reasonably low energy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XlsFOrtb8%253D&md5=0a21619ef3f43b0befe1b99ea9e83cf3

        (b) Braga, A. A. C.; Morgon, N. H.; Ujaque, G.; Maseras, F. Computational Characterization of the Role of the Base in the Suzuki–Miyaura Cross-Coupling Reaction. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 9298– 9307,  DOI: 10.1021/ja050583i
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37b
        Computational characterization of the role of the base in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction
        Braga, Ataualpa A. C.; Morgon, Nelson H.; Ujaque, Gregori; Maseras, Feliu
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (25), 9298-9307CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The role of the base in the transmetalation step of the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction is analyzed computationally by means of DFT calcns. with the Becke3LYP functional. The model system studied consists of Pd(CH:CH2)(PH3)2Br as the starting catalyst complex, CH2:CHB(OH)2 as the organoboronic acid, and OH- as the base. The two main mechanistic proposals, consisting of the base attacking first either the palladium complex or the organoboronic acid, are evaluated through geometry optimization of the corresponding intermediates and transition states. Supplementary calcns. are carried out on the uncatalyzed reaction and on a process where the starting complex is Pd(CH:CH2)(PH3)2(OH). These calcns., considered together with available exptl. data, strongly suggest that the main mechanism of transmetalation in the catalytic cycle starts with the reaction of the base and the organoboronic acid.

        (c) Braga, A. A. C.; Morgon, N. H.; Ujaque, G.; Lledós, A.; Maseras, F. Computational study of the transmetalation process in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling of aryls. J. Organomet. Chem. 2006, 691, 4459– 4466,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jorganchem.2006.02.015

        37c
        Computational study of the transmetalation process in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling of aryls
        Braga, Ataualpa A. C.; Morgon, Nelson H.; Ujaque, Gregori; Lledos, Agusti; Maseras, Feliu
        Journal of Organometallic Chemistry (2006), 691 (21), 4459-4466CODEN: JORCAI; ISSN:0022-328X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        The transmetalation step of the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling between aryl groups is analyzed by DFT calcns. with the Becke3LYP functional. The halide considered is PhBr, and the organoboronic acid is PhB(OH)2. The model catalyst is Pd(PH3)2, and the base, OH-. The transmetalation is considered to start from the Pd(Ph)(PH3)2Br complex, the product of the oxidative addn. The results are compared with those of a previous study on the analogous reaction with vinyl groups, and it is shown that the reaction mechanism is very similar.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtVSit7fF&md5=93d1a9bc7ef8ebdfc9a62245fd56ac7d

      38. 38
        Huang, C.-C.; Huang, Y.-C.; Hsieh, W.-C.; Chen, Y.-J.; Jiang, S.-K.; Chen, B.-H.; Hsu, I.-J.; Lee, J.-J. The effects of molecular structure and functional group of a rodlike Schiff base mesogen on blue phase stabilization in a chiral system. New J. Chem. 2019, 43, 1743– 1756,  DOI: 10.1039/c8nj04493g
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        The effects of molecular structure and functional group of a rodlike Schiff base mesogen on blue phase stabilization in a chiral system
        Huang, Chiung-Cheng; Huang, Yu-Chang; Hsieh, Wei-Cheng; Chen, Yen-Jung; Jiang, Shi-Kai; Chen, Bo-Hao; Hsu, I.-Jui; Lee, Jey-Jau
        New Journal of Chemistry (2019), 43 (4), 1743-1756CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two types of racemic rodlike Schiff base mesogens with -C=N- (type I) and -N=C- (type III) linkages were prepd. These mesogens possessed either difluoro substitutions at the inner-core position of the Ph ring or hydroxy group to form intramol. hydrogen bonding with an ester or/and imine linkage. When the appropriate concn. of chiral additive is doped into them, the incorporation of two fluoro substituents is more useful for blue phase (BP) stabilization than that of a hydroxy group near the ester linkage in Schiff base mesogens. BPI and BPII can be identified by reflectance spectra and polarized optical microscope images. BPII emerges easily on cooling when the appropriate chiral dopant ISO(6OBA)2 or chiral dopant S811 is doped into the Schiff base mesogen having only a hydroxy group near the ester linkage. Interestingly, BPI can be obsd. when 10-15 wt% ISO(6OBA)2 was doped into the difluoro substituted Schiff base mesogen during a heating process. The exptl. and mol. modeling results indicate that most of the difluorinated Schiff base mesogens with larger dipole moments exhibit wider BP ranges than their corresponding non-fluorinated homologues under the same chirality condition. In addn., wide BPs can be induced for racemic rodlike Schiff base mesogens in the chiral system and this is easier than that for racemic rodlike Schiff base mesogens. In Schiff base mesogens, the dipole moment is dominant for BP stabilization. However, the fluorine substituent effect is the main factor in Schiff base mesogens.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFejsL%252FE&md5=d3e1816d6a71a306ceff8af62d60a6dd

      41. 41
        Hanwell, M. D.; Curtis, D. E.; Lonie, D. C.; Vandermeersch, T.; Zurek, E.; Hutchison, G. R. Avogadro: an advanced semantic chemical editor, visualization, and analysis platform. J. Cheminf. 2012, 4, 17,  DOI: 10.1186/1758-2946-4-17
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        41
        Avogadro: an advanced semantic chemical editor, visualization, and analysis platform
        Hanwell, Marcus D.; Curtis, Donald E.; Lonie, David C.; Vandermeersch, Tim; Zurek, Eva; Hutchison, Geoffrey R.
        Journal of Cheminformatics (2012), 4 (), 17CODEN: JCOHB3; ISSN:1758-2946. (Chemistry Central Ltd.)
        Background: The Avogadro project has developed an advanced mol. editor and visualizer designed for cross-platform use in computational chem., mol. modeling, bioinformatics, materials science, and related areas. It offers flexible, high quality rendering, and a powerful plugin architecture. Typical uses include building mol. structures, formatting input files, and analyzing output of a wide variety of computational chem. packages. By using the CML file format as its native document type, Avogadro seeks to enhance the semantic accessibility of chem. data types. Results: The work presented here details the Avogadro library, which is a framework providing a code library and application programming interface (API) with three-dimensional visualization capabilities; and has direct applications to research and education in the fields of chem., physics, materials science, and biol. The Avogadro application provides a rich graphical interface using dynamically loaded plugins through the library itself. The application and library can each be extended by implementing a plugin module in C++ or Python to explore different visualization techniques, build/manipulate mol. structures, and interact with other programs. We describe some example extensions, one which uses a genetic algorithm to find stable crystal structures, and one which interfaces with the PackMol program to create packed, solvated structures for mol. dynamics simulations. The 1.0 release series of Avogadro is the main focus of the results discussed here. Conclusions: Avogadro offers a semantic chem. builder and platform for visualization and anal. For users, it offers an easy-to-use builder, integrated support for downloading from common databases such as PubChem and the Protein Data Bank, extg. chem. data from a wide variety of formats, including computational chem. output, and native, semantic support for the CML file format. For developers, it can be easily extended via a powerful plugin mechanism to support new features in org. chem., inorg. complexes, drug design, materials, biomols., and simulations.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsVGksLg%253D&md5=f10400f51db314afa780e99403ca748a
        open URL

        (a) James, C.; Raj, A. A.; Reghunathan, R.; Jayakumar, V. S.; Joe, I. H. Structural conformation and vibrational spectroscopic studies of 2,6-bis(p-N,N-dimethyl benzylidene)cyclohexanone using density functional theory. J. Raman Spectrosc. 2006, 37, 1381– 1392,  DOI: 10.1002/jrs.1554
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        43a
        Structural conformation and vibrational spectroscopic studies of 2,6-bis(p-N,N-dimethylaminobenzylidene) cyclohexanone using density functional theory
        James, C.; Raj, A. Amal; Reghunathan, R.; Jayakumar, V. S.; Joe, I. Hubert
        Journal of Raman Spectroscopy (2006), 37 (12), 1381-1392CODEN: JRSPAF; ISSN:0377-0486. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        NIR-FT Raman and FT-IR spectra of the crystd. 2,6-bis (p-N,N-dimethylaminobenzylidene)cyclohexanone (C24H28N2O) have been recorded in the region 3200-500 and 4000-400 cm-1, resp. The spectral interpretation has been done following full structure optimization and vibrational wavenumber calcns. based on the d. functional theory (DFT) using the std. B3LYP/6-31G* basis set. The predicted vibrational spectra are in excellent agreement with the expt., permitting an unambiguous assignment for the unusual downshifting of νC=O caused by expanded conjugation effects in the dienone system. The optimized geometry clearly demonstrates the 'half-chair' conformation of the central nonheterocyclic ring. The ring C-H stretching vibrational modes involving arom. hydrogen atoms participating in steric interaction have been obsd. with low intensities. There are valid structural and spectral bases for the enhancement of its bioactivity due to full charge transfer reaction by the substitution of the electron-donating 4-dimethylamino group into the aryl rings. The existence of intramol., C-H···O, improper, blue-shifted hydrogen bond was investigated by means of the natural bonding orbitals (NBO) anal. There are also slight dissimilarities in the bond lengths and endocyclic bond angles of both Ph rings due to the effect of the heavy substitution. The characteristic ring modes have also been assigned in detail.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (b) Szafran, M.; Komasa, A.; Bartoszak-Adamska, E. Crystal and molecular structure of 4-carboxypiperidinium chloride (4-piperidinecarboxylic acid hydrochloride). J. Mol. Struct. 2007, 827, 101– 107,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2006.05.012
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        43b
        Crystal and molecular structure of 4-carboxypiperidinium chloride (4-piperidinecarboxylic acid hydrochloride)
        Szafran, M.; Komasa, A.; Bartoszak-Adamska, E.
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2007), 827 (1-3), 101-107CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        4-Piperidinecarboxylic acid hydrochloride, 4PCAH·Cl, has been characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) calcns., and FTIR spectrum. The crystals of the title compd. at room temp. are orthorhombic, space group P212121, with a = 7.0504(4), b = 7.5070(5), c = 15.3110(9) Å, V = 810.37(9) Å3, and Z = 4. The piperidine ring is protonated and adopts a chair conformation with the COOH group in the equatorial position. In the crystal structure, the Cl- anion is connected with the carboxyl group via an O=C-O-H···Cl- hydrogen bond of 3.022(2) Å. The Cl- anion is addnl. engaged in two N(1)+ -H···Cl- hydrogen bonds (3.168(2) and 3.186(2) Å) and one relatively short N(1)+···Cl- electrostatic interaction (4.603(2) Å). Five conformers of the title compd. have been examd. by the B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) method. Powder FTIR spectra of the title compd. and its deuterated analog are consistent with the X-ray structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      44. 44
        Srnec, M.; Solomon, E. I. Frontier molecular orbital contributions to chlorination versus hydroxylation selectivity in the non-heme iron halogenase SyrB2. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2017, 139, 2396– 2407,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b11995
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44
        Frontier Molecular Orbital Contributions to Chlorination versus Hydroxylation Selectivity in the Non-Heme Iron Halogenase SyrB2
        Srnec, Martin; Solomon, Edward I.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (6), 2396-2407CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The ability of an FeIV=O intermediate in SyrB2 to perform chlorination vs. hydroxylation was computationally evaluated for different substrates that had been studied exptl. The π-trajectory for H-atom abstraction (FeIV=O oriented perpendicular to the C-H bond of substrate) was found to lead to the S = 2 five-coordinate HO-FeIII-Cl complex with the C• of the substrate, π-oriented relative to both the Cl- and OH- ligands. From this ferric intermediate, hydroxylation is thermodynamically favored, but chlorination is intrinsically more reactive due to the energy splitting between two key redox-active dπ* frontier MOs (FMOs). The splitting is detd. by the differential ligand field effect of Cl- vs. OH- on the Fe center. This makes chlorination effectively competitive with hydroxylation. Chlorination vs. hydroxylation selectivity is then detd. by the orientation of the substrate with respect to the HO-Fe-Cl plane that controls either the Cl- or OH- to rebound depending on the relative π-overlap with the substrate C radical. The differential contribution of the two FMOs to chlorination vs. hydroxylation selectivity in SyrB2 is related to a reaction mechanism that involves two asynchronous transfers: electron transfer from the substrate radical to the iron center followed by late ligand (Cl- or OH-) transfer to the substrate.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXht1Witr8%253D&md5=70b7957c9efa59bd0233ada17f996e55
        open URL
