        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44b
        Theoretical study of corrosion inhibition of amides and thiosemicarbazones
        Kandemirli, Fatma; Sagdinc, Seda
        Corrosion Science (2007), 49 (5), 2118-2130CODEN: CRRSAA; ISSN:0010-938X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        An examn. of quantum chem. and corrosion inhibition studies were carried out to investigate whether any clear links exist between the results of quantum chem. calcns. and the exptl. efficiencies of urea (U), thiourea (TU), acetamide (A), thioacetamide (TA), semicarbazide (SC), thiosemicarbazide (TSC), methoxybenzaldehydethiosemicarbazone (MBTSC), 2-acetylpyridine-(4-phenyl)thiosemicarbazone (2AP4PTSC), 2-acetylpyridine-(4-methyl)thiosemicarbazone (2AP4MTSC), benzoin thiosemicarbazone (BZOTSC) and benzil thiosemicarbazone (BZITSC) being corrosion inhibitors. The quantum chem. calcns. have been performed by using DFT, ab-initio MO and semi-empirical methods for some amides and thiosemicarbozone derivs. being corrosion inhibitors. The HOMO energy, LUMO energy, the HOMO-LUMO energy gap, dipole moments (μ), charges on the C, O, N, S atoms, the total energies of the mols. and the polarizabilities 〈α〉, the coeffs. of the development of the MO over the AO corresponding to atoms between which a new bond is established have been calcd. The results of quantum chem. calcns. and exptl. efficiencies of inhibitors were subjected to correlation anal. We have reached the conclusion that the synthesis of better corrosion inhibitors can be achieved by controlling all electronic properties and parameters of a selected group of mols.

        Synthesis, characterization, crystal structures, Hirshfeld surface analysis and DFT computational studies of new Schiff Bases derived from Phenylhydrazine
        Parvarinezhad, Sakineh; Salehi, Mehdi
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2020), 1222 (), 128780CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        In this research, four novel ligands I [R1 = H, NO2; R2 = 4-MeO, 5-Br, Ph] were synthesized from hydrazine derivs. The hydrazine compds. via reacting 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine with 2-hydroxy-4-methoxybenzaldehyde/2-hydroxy- 5-bromobenzaldehyde/2-hydroxy-naphtaldehyde and 4-nitrophenylhydrazine with 2-hydroxy-4-methoxybenzaldehyde were synthesized, characterized using FT-IR, Raman and UV-Vis spectrum and it structure were confirmed by X-ray diffraction studies. Novel compds. were recovered to crystallize systems in monoclinic, orthorhombic, triclinic and monoclinic, crystal structures with P21/n, Pbcn, P-1, and P21/c space groups in ligands. Afterwards, present study compared exptl. parameters in UV-Vis and FT-IR spectra with theor. values. The results showed that at B3LYP/6-311 + G (d, p) level, DFT was able to properly reproduce structure of title ligands. Moreover, Hirshfeld surface (HS) anal., particularly dnorm surface and FPs (fingerprint plots), were employed to decode intermol. interactions in crystal system and contribution of component units in construction of 3D architecture. These examns. presented general description of such inter-contact interactions by means of an attractive graphical approach by 3D Hirshfeld surfaces and 2D fingerprint plots derived from the surfaces. Hirshfeld surface anal. indicated dominant role of various hydrogen intermol. interactions such as H···H, C···H/H···C and O···H/H···O for all compds. and H···Br contacts for ligand I [R1 = NO2, R2 = 5-Br] (because of the) into crystal packing which were discussed.

        Soleimani Amiri, Somayeh; Makarem, Somayeh; Ahmar, Hamid; Ashenagar, Samaneh

        The structural, electronic, and spectroscopic properties of 4-methyl-5-((5-phenyl-1,3,4 oxadiazol-2-yl)thio)benzene-1,2-diol (MPOTB) have been carried out at ab initio and DFT levels.         47a
        Electrophilicity Index
        Parr, Robert G.; Szentpaly, Laszlo v.; Liu, Shubin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1999), 121 (9), 1922-1924CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Prompted by a recent paper by Maynard and co-workers (Maynard, A. T.; Huang, M.; Rice, W. G.; Covel, D. G.; Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1998, 95, 11578), we propose that a specific property of a chem. species, the square of its electronegativity divided by its chem. hardness, be taken as defining its electrophilicity index. We tabulate this quantity for a no. of at. and mol. species, for two different models of the energy-electron no. relationships, and we show that it measures the second-order energy change of an electrophile as it is satd. with electrons.

First Theoretical Framework of Triphenylamine-Dicyanovinylene-Based Nonlinear Optical Dyes: Structural Modification of π-Linkers. J. Phys. Chem.         49
        First Theoretical Framework of Triphenylamine-Dicyanovinylene-Based Nonlinear Optical Dyes: Structural Modification of π-Linkers
        Khan, Muhammad Usman; Khalid, Muhammad; Ibrahim, Muhammad; Braga, Ataualpa Albert Carmo; Safdar, Muhammad; Al-Saadi, Abdulaziz A.; Janjua, Muhammad Ramzan Saeed Ashraf
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2018), 122 (7), 4009-4018CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        This work was inspired by a previous report [Janjua, M.R.S.A. Inorg. Chem. 2012, 51, 11306-11314] in which the nonlinear optical (NLO) response strikingly improved with double heteroarom. rings. Herein, series of triphenylamine-dicyanovinylene based donor-π-acceptor dyes had been designed by structural tailoring of π-conjugated linkers and theor. descriptions of their mol. NLO properties were reported. D. functional theory and time-dependent d. functional theory calcns. were performed on optimized geometries to elucidate the electronic structures, absorption spectra, and NLO properties and also to shed light on how structural modification influences the NLO properties. The simulated absorption spectra results indicate that all of the dyes showed the max. absorbance wavelength in the visible region. The LUMO-HOMO energy gaps of all of the dyes have been found smaller, which results in large NLO response. Calcn. of natural bond orbital anal. reveals that electrons successfully migrated from donor to acceptor via π-conjugated linkers and a charge sepn. state was formed. High NLO response revealed that this class of metal free org. dyes possess eye-catching and remarkably large first hyperpolarizability values, esp. D8 with highest 〈α〉 and βtot computed to be 771.80 and 139 075.05 au, resp. Our research presented a vital confirmation for controlling the kinds of π-conjugated linker that was a significant approach for the design of new appealing NLO compds. This theor. framework also highlighted the NLO properties of org. dyes that can be valuable for their uses in modern hi-tech applications.

        Frontier molecular, natural bond orbital, UV-vis spectral study, solvent influence on geometric parameters, vibrational frequencies and solvation energies of 8-hydroxyquinoline
        Khalid, Muhammad; Ali, Muhammad; Aslam, Muhammad; Sumrra, Sajjad Hussain; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Raza, Nadeem; Kumar, Naresh; Imran, Muhammad
        International Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research (2017), 8 (2), 457-469CODEN: IJPSTT; ISSN:0975-8232. (International Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research)
        N-heterocyclic compds. have extensive biol. and pharmaceutical applications. 8-Hydroxyquinoline (8-HQ) also plays a significant role in many fields of life. The excellent biol. significance of the 8-HQ prompted us to extend the DFT based studies. The frontier MOs (FMOs), UV-Vis and solvation model based studies remained unknown. Therefore, we intended to study the natural bond orbital, FMOs, UV-Vis, thermodn. properties and medium influence on solvation energies, dipole moment, FT-IR and FT-Raman using polarizable continuum model (PCM) and d.-based solvation model (SMD). The electronic properties of mol. were calcd. by M06-2X/6-31G (d,P) and B3LYP/6-31G (d,p) level of theories. The solvent influence on the geometric parameters, FT-IR and FT-Raman were studied by B3LYP /6-31G(d) method. A good correspondence is found between the optimized parameters and the reported X-ray data. Natural bond orbital reveals that the max. stabilization energy reached up to 39.64 kJ/mol which is responsible for extra stability of the mol. In solvated 8-HQ, a significant medium effects on FT-IR and FT-Raman intensities is obsd. The intensities enhanced from gas to solvent phase. The solvation free energies are found to be -28.710 and -39.456 kJ/mol in PCM and SMD models resp. FMOs suggested that this mol. contain less hardness and larger softness values. These findings reveal that the mol. might be bioactive.

        Phytochemical, crystal structure, spectroscopic, DFT based non covalent interactions and non-linear optical studies of Neurada procumbens
        Ibrahim, Muhammad; Abbas, Mazhar; Khalid, Muhammad; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Hussain, Ajaz; Ullah, Asmat; Hussain, Amjad
        Journal of the Chemical Society of Pakistan (2018), 40 (4), 749-760CODEN: JCSPDF ISSN:. (Chemical Society of Pakistan)
        In this study, two compds.: 4-(3-bromopropoxy)-3-methoxy Ph methanol (1) and 4-(3-bromopropoxy)-3-methoxybenzaldehyde (2) have been isolated from Neurada procumbens for the first time. Their structures have been elucidated by EI-MS, HR-EI-MS, HR-FAB-MS, 1H and 13C-NMR and XRD crystallog. techniques. These compds. have been further investigated using d. functional theory (DFT) at M06-2X level of theory with 6-311+G(d,p) basis set combination to obtain optimized geometry. The optimized geometrical parameters were found in good agreement with the XRD results. Natural bond orbital (NBO) anal. have been executed using M06-2X/6-311+G(d, p) level of theory which predicted the hydrogen bonding and hyper- conjugative interaction of both crystals. Frontier MO (FMOs) anal. and mol. electrostatic potential (MEP) surface studies were carried out using B3LYP/6-311+G(d,p) level to calc. EHOMO-ELUMO gap, possible sites and relative reactivities towards nucleophilic and electrophilic attack. Finally, nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of the title mols. were computed with B3LYP/6-311+G (d,p) method which is found greater as compared to the ref. mol. (urea) demonstrating that the mols. might have convincingly good NLO properties.

      52. 52
        (a) Medishetty, R.; Zaręba, J. K.; Mayer, D.; Samoć, M.; Fischer, R. A. Nonlinear optical properties, upconversion and lasing in metal-organic frameworks. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2017, 46, 4976– 5004,  DOI: 10.1039/c7cs00162b
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        52a
        Nonlinear optical properties, upconversion and lasing in metal-organic frameworks
        Medishetty, Raghavender; Zareba, Jan K.; Mayer, David; Samoc, Marek; Fischer, Roland A.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2017), 46 (16), 4976-5004CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The building block modular approach that lies behind coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) results not only in a plethora of materials that can be obtained but also in a vast array of material properties that could be aimed at. Optical properties appear to be particularly predetd. by the character of individual structural units and by the intricate interplay between them. Indeed, the "design principles" shaping the optical properties of these materials seem to be well explored for luminescence and second-harmonic generation (SHG) phenomena; these have been covered in numerous previous reviews. Herein, we shine light on CPs and MOFs as optical media for state-of-the-art photonic phenomena such as multi-photon absorption, triplet-triplet annihilation (TTA) and stimulated emission. In the first part of this review we focus on the nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of CPs and MOFs, with a closer look at the two-photon absorption property. We discuss the scope of applicability of most commonly used measurement techniques (Z-scan and two-photon excited fluorescence (TPEF)) that can be applied for proper detn. of the NLO properties of these materials; in particular, we suggest recommendations for their use, along with a discussion of the best reporting practices of NLO parameters. We also outline design principles, employing both intramol. and intermol. strategies, that are necessary for maximizing the NLO response. A review of recent literature on two-, three- and multi-photon absorption in CPs and MOFs is further supplemented with application-oriented processes such as two-photon 3D patterning and data storage. Addnl., we provide an overview of the latest achievements in the field of frequency doubling (SHG) and tripling (third-harmonic generation, THG) in these materials. Apart from nonlinear processes, in the next sections we also target the photonic properties of MOFs that benefit from their porosity, and resulting from this their ability to serve as containers for optically-active mols. Thus, we survey dye@MOF composites as novel media in which efficient upconversion via triplet energy migration (TEM) occurs as well as materials for stimulated emission and multi-photon pumped lasing. Prospects for producing lasing as an intrinsic property of MOFs has also been discussed. Overall, further development of the optical processes highlighted herein should allow for realization of various photonic, data storage, biomedical and optoelectronic applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVSis7jN&md5=c2c3c2a793c85c2bc81fd4aec53c6a05
        open URL
        .
        (b) Manjunatha, K. B.; Rajarao, R.; Umesh, G.; Ramachandra Bhat, B.; Poornesh, P. Optical nonlinearity, limiting and switching characteristics of novel ruthenium metal-organic complex. Opt. Mater. 2017, 72, 513– 517,  DOI: 10.1016/j.optmat.2017.06.051
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        52b
        Optical nonlinearity, limiting and switching characteristics of novel ruthenium metal-organic complex
        Manjunatha, K. B.; Rajarao, Ravindra; Umesh, G.; Ramachandra Bhat, B.; Poornesh, P.
        Optical Materials (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2017), 72 (), 513-517CODEN: OMATET; ISSN:0925-3467. (Elsevier B.V.)
        We report the nonlinear optical properties of Ruthenium metal complex, a promising org. material for use in scientific and technol. applications. The thin films of newly synthesized ruthenium metal-org. complex were fabricated using spin coating technique. Z-scan and degenerate four wave mixing (DFWM) techniques used to ext. the third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) parameters. The data reveals the investigated material exhibited relatively large NLO properties. The pump-probe expts. shows that the switch-on and off times of the material were in the order of μs at different pump intensities and the energy dependent transmission studies reveal good limiting property of the material in nanosecond regime.

        (c) Khan, I.; Khalid, M.; Adeel, M.; Niaz, S. I.; Shafiq, I.; Muhammad, S.; Braga, A. A. C. Palladium-catalyzed synthesis of 5-(arylated) pyrimidines, their characterization, electronic communication, and non-linear optical evaluations. J. Mol. Struct. 2021, 1237, 130408,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2021.130408
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        52c
        Palladium-catalyzed synthesis of 5-(arylated) pyrimidines, their characterization, electronic communication, and non-linear optical evaluations
        Khan, Ilham; Khalid, Muhammad; Adeel, Muhammad; Niaz, Shah Irum; Shafiq, Iqra; Muhammad, Shabbir; Braga, Ataualpa Albert Carmo
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2021), 1237 (), 130408CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        In this study, new derivs. of pyrimidines I [R1 = 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-Ph, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] were synthesized through Suzuki-Miyaura coupling and assessed by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, FT-IR and UV/Visible anal. Furthermore, computational study such as spectroscopic, frontier MO (FMO), natural bond orbital (NBO) and the mol. electrostatic potential (MEP) was performed at M06/6-311G** to obtain comprehensive insights into electronic communications and the structural property relationship for synthesized compds. I. The max. exptl. absorption (λExp) for compds. I [R1 = 4-Ph, 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] was obtained at 260, 301, 248, and 233 nm, resp. in methanol, which displayed good agreement with theor. (λDFT) result 279, 298, 247, and 233 nm, resp. Moreover, different functional(s) such as HF, M06, M062X, CAM-B3LYP, and LC-BLYP with basis sets 6-311G** were utilized to compute the av. polarizability α, total dipole moment (μtot) and hyperpolarizability (βtot) values. Among the tested methods, highest μtot value (3.5465 D) was obsd. for compd.I [R1 = 2,3-dichloro] and the lowest value (0.2680 D) for compd. I [R1 = 4-trifluoromethoxy] through HF method. Consequently, the LC-BLYP method also showed the highest μtot value (3.4689 D) for compd. I [R1 = 2,3-dichloro] and the lowest value (0.3123 D) of compd. I [R1 = 4-trifluoromethoxy]. Moreover, other methods: CAM-B3LYP, M062X, and M06 showed almost similar values for all compds. I with similar trends. The M06 method showed the largest α values (190.779, 149.331, 130.430 and 138.964 a.u.) for compds. I [R1 = 4-Ph, 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] resp. In contrast, the HF method showed the least α values (178.166, 140.356, 121.848, and 128.994 a.u.) for compds. I [R1 = 4-Ph, 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] resp. The other methods (CAMB3LYP, M062X, and LC-BLYP) indicated nearly parallel (α) values. Moreover, the (βtot) values (604.898, 344.234, 41.628, and 299.958 a.u.) obtained with M06 method for compds. I [R1 = 4-Ph, 4-methylsulfanyl, 4-trifluoromethoxy, 2,3-dichloro] resp., were higher compared with urea (βtot = 69.399 a.u.).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXptVWmt7s%253D&md5=878c44155f3f2a8a47e357d27fdc06cf
        open URL
      53. 53
        Khalid, M.; Arshad, M. N.; Tahir, M. N.; Asiri, A. M.; Naseer, M. M.; Ishaq, M.; Khan, M. U.; Shafiq, Z. An efficient synthesis, structural (SC-XRD) and spectroscopic (FTIR, 1HNMR, MS spectroscopic) characterization of novel benzofuran-based hydrazones: An experimental and theoretical studies. J. Mol. Struct. 2020, 1216, 128318,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2020.128318
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        53
        An efficient synthesis, structural (SC-XRD) and spectroscopic (FTIR, 1HNMR, MS spectroscopic) characterization of novel benzofuran-based hydrazones: An experimental and theoretical studies
        Khalid, Muhammad; Arshad, Muhammad Nadeem; Tahir, Muhammad Nawaz; Asiri, Abdullah M.; Naseer, Muhammad Moazzam; Ishaq, Muhammad; Khan, Muhammad Usman; Shafiq, Zahid
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2020), 1216 (), 128318CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Herein, the benzofuran-based hydrazones derivs. such as N'-(1-(benzofuran-2-yl)ethylidene)isonicotinohydrazide (BEINH), N'-(1-(benzofuran-2-yl)ethylidene)nicotine-hydrazide (BFENH) and N'-(1-(benzofuran-2-yl)ethylidene)-2-chlorobenzohydrazide (BECBH)were synthesized and characterized using FTIR, 1HNMR, MS spectroscopic and SC-XRD techniques. Furthermore, the structural geometrical parameters, vibrational bands, natural bond orbitals (NBOs), natural population anal. (NPA), mol. electrostatic potential (MEP), linear and nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of the BEINH, BFENH and BECBH were rationalized applying B3LYP level of d. functional theory (DFT) inclusive of 6-311+G(d,p) basis set. Consequently, an excellent complement between the exptl. data and the DFT based results was attained. The most dominant hyper conjugative interactions with assocd. stabilization energies of 67.52, 59.61 and 48.35 kcal/mol were found for BEINH, BFENH and BECBH resp. which may become the cause of their stability. The band gaps (Egap) of BEINH, BFENH and BECBH were rationalized to be 3.814, 3.903 and 3.727eV resp. which can be efficiently polarized the chem. structures. The descending order of av. linear polarizability for title compds. is as: BECBH > BEINH > BFENH. It was conferred that highest value of βtot was obtained for BEINH as 3591.872 (a.u) and the smallest value was obtained for BECBHi.e. 2242.707 (a.u) among title compds. The overall decreasing order of βtot was obsd. as: BEINH > BFENH > BECBH. Addnl., NLO properties of title compds. were found larger than ref. material.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXovVCnsL8%253D&md5=3e14a8be2a42bdc23a238816cd694ff4
        open URL
      54. 54
        Lash, T. D. Organic Chemistry, Carey Francis, A., Ed.; ACS Publications, 1996.

      55. 55
        Hameed, K.; Rubina, S.; Raheel, A. Design, synthesis, docking and in vitro antibacterial study of fluoro substituted schiff bases. J. Chem. Soc. Pak. 2018, 40, 782– 791
        [CAS], Google Scholar
        55
        Design, synthesis, docking and in vitro antibacterial study of fluoro substituted Schiff bases
        Hameed, Kehkashan; Gilani, Syeda Rubina; Raheel, Ahmad; Taj, Babar; Iftikhar, Syed Hussan; Imtiaz-ud-Din; Sadiqa, Ayesha; Aslam, Ambreen
        Journal of the Chemical Society of Pakistan (2018), 40 (4), 782-791CODEN: JCSPDF ISSN:. (Chemical Society of Pakistan)
        Five new fluoro-substituted imines were synthesized by the reaction of different aldehydes with fluoro-substituted anilines. The synthesized compds. were characterized by elemental (CHN) anal., FT-IR and multinuclear (1H and 13C) NMR spectroscopy. These compds. were also preliminary analyzed for bactericidal and anti-cancer activities. Mol. docking of these newly synthesized compds. supports the exptl. results (bactericidal activity). The data suggests that these compds. display favorable bactericidal and anti-cancer activity and may prove potential candidate for drugs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtlynur3L&md5=23a4306706e3326501e478358e679cde

      56. 56
        Guzel, B.; Avsar, G. Fluorus Schiff base ligands and their nickel(II) complexes: synthesis, characterization and solubility properties in supercritical CO2. Inorg. Chem.: Indian J. 2008, 3, 1– 4
        [CAS], Google Scholar
        56
        Fluorus Schiff base ligands and their nickel(II) complexes: synthesis, characterization and solubility properties in supercritical CO2
        Guzel, Bilgehan; Avsar, Gokturk
        Inorganic Chemistry: An Indian Journal (2008), 3 (1), 1-4CODEN: ICRIBA ISSN:. (Trade Science Inc.)
        New supercrit. carbon dioxide sol. ligands, (E)-2-((3-(trifluoromethyl)phenylimino)methyl)phenol, (E)-2-((4-(trifluoromethyl)phenylimino)methyl)phenol, (E)-2-methoxy-6-((3-(trifluoromethyl)phenylimino)methyl)phenol, (E)-2-methoxy-6-((4-(trifluoromethyl)phenylimino)methyl)phenol and their nickel(II) complexes have been prepd. and characterized by spectroscopic methods and elemental anal. The soly. of the synthesized compds. was measured at 343.15K and 172.4 bar in supercrit. carbon dioxide.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtFGgsbnJ&md5=9ce8289f93eb3ce3b68948a69878e83b

      57. 57
        Mohandas, T.; Inbaseelan, C. R. D.; Saravanan, S.; Sakthivel, P. Glycine-D-tartaric acid (1/1). Acta Crystallogr., Sect. E: Struct. Rep. Online 2013, 69, o236,  DOI: 10.1107/s1600536813000822
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        57
        Glycine-d-tartaric acid (1/1)
        Mohandas, T.; Inbaseelan, C. Ranjith Dev; Saravanan, S.; Sakthivel, P.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section E: Structure Reports Online (2013), 69 (2), o236CODEN: ACSEBH; ISSN:1600-5368. (International Union of Crystallography)
        In the title co-crystal, C2H5NO2·C4H6O6, the glycine mol. is present in the zwitterion form. In the tartaric acid mol. there is a short intramol. O-H···O contact. In the crystal, the tartaric acid mols. are linked via pairs of O-H···O H bonds, forming inversion dimers. These dimers are linked via a no. of O-H···O and N-H···O H bonds involving the two components, forming a three-dimensional network. Crystallog. data and at. coordinates are given.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvV2qsLg%253D&md5=257d76601b75ec864b52f295563ed225

      58. 58
        Sanz, R.; Martínez, F.; Orcajo, G.; Wojtas, L.; Briones, D. Synthesis of a honeycomb-like Cu-based metal-organic framework and its carbon dioxide adsorption behaviour. Dalton Trans. 2013, 42, 2392– 2398,  DOI: 10.1039/c2dt32138f
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        58
        Synthesis of a honeycomb-like Cu-based metal-organic framework and its carbon dioxide adsorption behaviour
        Sanz, Raul; Martinez, Fernando; Orcajo, Gisela; Wojtas, Lukasz; Briones, David
        Dalton Transactions (2013), 42 (7), 2392-2398CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Herein, the authors report on a new Cu-based MOF material, Cu2(dhtp), structurally homologous to the honeycomb-like M2(dhtp) series. This has been crystd. under solvothermal conditions using copper nitrate and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid as an org. linker, being the nature of the co-solvent in the synthesis media an important variable over the final phys. properties of the material. The presence of isopropanol as a co-solvent gives a pure cryst. phase with textural properties comparable to M2(dhtp) homologs. The interesting results in CO2 adsorption properties of this new material, esp. its isosteric heat of adsorption, make it a suitable MOF to be further evaluated under real conditions of industrial CO2 capture.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtFGjurs%253D&md5=10020bda96703d92dfc98d38db441cdd
        open URL
      59. 59
        Sheldrick, G. M. A short history ofSHELX. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A: Cryst. Phys., Diffr., Theor. Gen. Crystallogr. 2008, 64, 112– 122,  DOI: 10.1107/s0108767307043930
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        59
        A short history of SHELX
        Sheldrick, George M.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
        An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e
        open URL
      60. 60
        Kratzert, D.; Holstein, J. J.; Krossing, I. DSR: enhanced modelling and refinement of disordered structures withSHELXL. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2015, 48, 933– 938,  DOI: 10.1107/s1600576715005580
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        60
        DSR: enhanced modelling and refinement of disordered structures with SHELXL
        Kratzert, Daniel; Holstein, Julian J.; Krossing, Ingo
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2015), 48 (3), 933-938CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:1600-5767. (International Union of Crystallography)
        One of the remaining challenges in single-crystal structure refinement is the proper description of disorder in crystal structures. This paper describes a computer program that performs semi-automatic modeling of disordered moieties in SHELXL [Sheldrick (2015). Acta Cryst. C71, 3-8.]. The new program contains a database that includes mol. fragments and their corresponding stereochem. restraints, and a placement procedure to place these fragments on the desired position in the unit cell. The program is also suitable for speeding up model building of well ordered crystal structures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXpsFaltLk%253D&md5=5393f4ad697d044f609eaf744743f2ff
        open URL
      61. 61
        Chuchuryukin, A. V.; Huang, R.; Lutz, M.; Chadwick, J. C.; Spek, A. L.; Van Koten, G. NCN-Pincer Metal Complexes (Ti, Cr, V, Zr, Hf, and Nb) of the Phebox Ligand (S,S)-2,6-Bis(4′-isopropyl-2′-oxazolinyl)phenyl. Organometallics 2011, 30, 2819– 2830,  DOI: 10.1021/om200170b
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        61
        NCN-Pincer metal complexes (Ti, Cr, V, Zr, Hf, and Nb) of the Phebox ligand (S,S)-2,6-bis(4'-isopropyl-2'-oxazolinyl)phenyl
        Chuchuryukin, Alexey V.; Huang, Rubin; Lutz, Martin; Chadwick, John C.; Spek, Anthony L.; van Koten, Gerard
        Organometallics (2011), 30 (10), 2819-2830CODEN: ORGND7; ISSN:0276-7333. (American Chemical Society)
        Group IVB and VB metal NCN-pincer complexes of chiral 2,6-bis(2-oxazolinyl)phenyl ligands were prepd. as efficient catalysts for coordination polymn. of ethylene. Reaction of (S,S)-2,6-bis(4'-isopropyl-2'-oxazolinyl)phenyllithium (iPr-Phebox-Li) (2a) with 4,4'-bis[P-(chlorogold(I))diphenylphosphino]biphenyl [(dppbp)(AuCl)2] (5) afforded the new, bimetallic gold complex 4,4'-bis[P-(η1-C-iPr-Phebox-gold)diphenylphosphino]biphenyl [(P-Au(η1-C-iPr-Phebox))2(dppbp)] (6). Transmetalation of 6 with 2 equiv of Cl3MX (MX = TiOiPr, VCl, CrPy, ZrCl, HfCl, NbO) afforded the corresponding bis-monopincer compds. [MCl2X(iPr-Phebox)] (7a-c, M = Ti, V, Cr) and [MCl2X(iPr-Phebox)]2 (7a-c, M = Zr, Hf, Nb) in high yields and the gold starting material 5, which could be quant. recovered and reused. The structures in the solid state of the digold compd. 6, the monopincer compds. [(R-Phebox)Au(PPh3)] (4a,b, R = iPr, tBu), and a no. of Phebox-ETM complexes (7a, 7b, 7c, 8a, 8b, and 8c) were obtained. In each of these structures the i-Pr-Phebox monoanion is mer-N,C,N-tridentate bonded. The monopincer Phebox-Zr and -Hf compds. are dimeric because of two bridging chlorides, while the corresponding Nb compd. has bridging oxygen atoms. Reaction of 6 with iron(III) chloride resulted in the formation of a N4(FeCl2)2 complex, characterized by x-ray crystal structure detn., comprising a bridging, tetradentate N4 ligand formed by C-C coupling of two Phebox anions to a 2,2',6,6'-tetrasubstituted 1,1'-biphenyl species. The new Phebox complexes 7 and 8 have been tested as olefin polymn. precatalysts. Rapid catalyst deactivation was obsd. in ethene polymn. under homogeneous conditions, whereas stable activity was obtained after immobilization on MgCl2-based supports. From preliminary investigations on the reaction of 8a with either methylmagnesium chloride or methyllithium we assume that the low reactivity in homogeneous polymn. is due to the alkylation of the Phebox ligand.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXkvVOqurk%253D&md5=60afdf1a6b6329ebf6ec51cdfbe9e7cc
        open URL
      62. 62
        Macrae, C. F.; Sovago, I.; Cottrell, S. J.; Galek, P. T. A.; McCabe, P.; Pidcock, E.; Platings, M.; Shields, G. P.; Stevens, J. S.; Towler, M.; Wood, P. A. Mercury 4.0: From visualization to analysis, design and prediction. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2020, 53, 226– 235,  DOI: 10.1107/s1600576719014092
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        62
        Mercury 4.0: from visualization to analysis, design and prediction
        Macrae, Clare F.; Sovago, Ioana; Cottrell, Simon J.; Galek, Peter T. A.; McCabe, Patrick; Pidcock, Elna; Platings, Michael; Shields, Greg P.; Stevens, Joanna S.; Towler, Matthew; Wood, Peter A.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2020), 53 (1), 226-235CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:1600-5767. (International Union of Crystallography)
        The program Mercury, developed at the Cambridge Crystallog. Data Center, was originally designed primarily as a crystal structure visualization tool. Over the years the fields and scientific communities of chem. crystallog. and crystal engineering have developed to require more advanced structural anal. software. Mercury has evolved alongside these scientific communities and is now a powerful anal., design and prediction platform which goes a lot further than simple structure visualization.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXitlKhu7k%253D&md5=c16558a671e926b2350758305109b34c
        open URL
      63. 63
        Farrugia, L. J. WinGXandORTEP for Windows: an update. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2012, 45, 849– 854,  DOI: 10.1107/s0021889812029111
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        63
        WinGX and ORTEP for Windows: an update
        Farrugia, Louis J.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2012), 45 (4), 849-854CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (International Union of Crystallography)
        The WinGX suite provides a complete set of programs for the treatment of small-mol. single-crystal diffraction data, from data redn. and processing, structure soln., model refinement and visualization, and metric anal. of mol. geometry and crystal packing, to final report prepn. in the form of a CIF. It includes several well known pieces of software and provides a repository for programs when the original authors no longer wish to, or are unable to, maintain them. It also provides menu items to execute external software, such as the SIR and SHELX suites of programs. The program ORTEP for Windows provides a graphical user interface (GUI) for the classic ORTEP program, which is the original software for the illustration of anisotropic displacement ellipsoids. The GUI code provides input capabilities for a wide variety of file formats, and extra functionality such as geometry calcns. and ray-traced outputs. The programs WinGX and ORTEP for Windows have been distributed over the internet for about 15 years, and this article describes some of the more modern features of the programs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtVKltbzK&md5=0b5b2b5facbaafdd6bbbb80e581bf3be
        open URL

      • Crystallographic data for MPIF (CIF)

      • Crystallographic data for FPIN (CIF)

      • SC-XRD; experimental details of MFIP and FPIN; enrichment ratio for pairs of chemical species (X, X) and (X, Y) in compound MFIP and compound FPIN; NBO analysis; dipole polarizability, polarizability, second-order hyperpolarizability and their major contributing tensor (a.u), wavelengths (λmax), energies, and oscillator strengths; off-set π···π stacking interaction in the crystal packing of FPIN; comparison of the remaining 2D plots of MFIP (a–d, i–h) with FPIN (e–h, m,n); summary of interactions of an atom present inside the HS with the neighboring molecules; simulated absorption spectra of MFIP and FPIN; FMOs of the entitled compounds; and bond lengths in Å and bond angles in ° for MFIP and FPIN (PDF)
